titleStmt.title: The Three Lords and Three Ladies of London 1588
titleStmt.author: Wilson, Robert

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Three lords and three ladies of London
Three lordes and three ladies of London
Stately morall of the three lords of London.

div.p: The pleasant and stately moral, of the three lords and three ladies of London.

With the great joy and pomp, solemnised at their marriages: commically interlaced with much honest mirth, for pleasure and recreation, among many moral observations and other important matters of due regard. by R. W.
London. Printed by R. Jones, at the rose and crown near Holborn bridge. 1590.

list.item: Policy, the thrée lords of London. Wit. their pages.
Pomp, the thrée lords of London. Wealth. their pages.
Pleasure, the thrée lords of London. Will. their pages.
Pride, three lords of Spain, shame, their pages,
Ambition, three lords of Spain, treachery, their pages,
Tyranny, three lords of Spain, terror, their pages,
Simplicity, a poor free man of London.
Diligence, a post, or an officer.
Falsehood. two that belong to fraud and dissimulation.
Double dealing. two that belong to fraud and dissimulation.

div.stage: Enter for the preface, a lady very richly attired, representing London, having two angels before her, and two after her with bright rapiers in their hands.

lg.l: Lo, gentles, thus the lord doth London guard,
Not for my sake, but for his own delight:
For all in vain the sentinels watch and ward,
Except he keep the city day and night.
Now may my foes in vain both spurn and spite,
My foes I mean, that London represent,
Guarded from heaven by angels excellent.
This blessing is not my sole benefit,
All England is, and so preserved hath been,
Not by man's strength, his policy and wit,
But by a power and providence unseen.
Even for the love wherewith God loves our Queen:
In whom, for whom, by whom we do possess
More grace, more good, than London can express.
And that hath bred our plenty and our peace,
And they do breed the sports you come to see,
And joy it is, that I enjoy increase,
My former fruits were lovely ladies three,
Now of three lords to talk is London's glee.
Whose deeds I wish may to your liking frame,
For London bids you welcome to the same.

div.head: The pleasant and stately moral of the three lords of London.
div.stage: Enter the three lords and their pages: first, policy with his page wit before him, bearing a shield: the impreze, a tortoise, the word, providens securus. Next pomp, with his page wealth bearing his shield, the word, glory sans peer: the impreze a lily. Last, pleasure, his page Wil, his impreze, a falcon, the word, pour temps: Pol. attired in black, pomp in rich robes, and pleasure in colours.

sp.speaker: Policy.
sp.l: Here I advance my shield and hang it up,
To challenge him whoever dare deny,
That one of those thrée London ladies rare
Ought not of right be matched with policy:
A London lord, the which I represent.
Pom. And pomp provides his challenge in his word,
(Glory sans peer) claiming the one of them,
Not by compulsion, but by common right,
Yet maugre men my shield is here advanced
For one matchless, a London lady best
Beseemeth pomp (A London lord) to have.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Pleasure hath soared as doth his impreze show,
To look aloof on earthly ladies all,
Yet never could my curious eye discern
A dame of worth, for London's pleasure's love,
But one, and she doth shine as silver dove.
Of self bred soil, of London is her race,
For whom in challenge I my shield advance.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Thus each in honour of his mistress
And in regard of his well daring mind,
Hath here ymprizde the challenge of his right:
But lordings both, and brothers bred and sworn,
a caution must be had in this conceit,
That all our thoughts aspire not to one heaven,
Nor all our ships do sail for one self haven,
I mean that all our suits and services
We tend and tender to one only dame,
All choosing one, refusing th'other two.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: A great mislike amongst us that might breed.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: I seek but one and her unto myself.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: And one with I sans partner of my loves.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: It stands with honour to be sole or none.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Whom lovest thou pleasure?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Hark ye. Whisper in his ear.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Lush, ye lie.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: If my master were a soldier, that word would have the stab.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Well Will, still you'll be a saucy scab.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Why pleasure? Pomp hath chosen Lucre's love.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Why pomp? But pleasure honour's lucre most.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: And policy may lady lucre gain
Before you both: but let us not contend,
For Nemo doth the ladies prisoners keep,
Though they were slandered late with liberty
And marriage to three far born foreigners.
Then first it fits we practise their release,
And see them, and by sight our liking place,
For yet we love as gossips tell their tales,
By hearsay: fame, not favour hath us yet inflamed.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Lord policy with reason hath discuss pleasure consent, and so our love shall hold.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Ye never found that London's pleasure erred
From reason, or from pomp and policy.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Come on sir boy, attend you well your charge,To his page wit.
Wait in this place to watch and ward this shield,
If any man in honour of his love,
So hardy be with stroke of sword to attaint
This shield, and challenge him that hereby challengeth,
Say for thy lord as should a trusty page,
That policy doth dare him to perform
A hardy task than common challengers.
If he demand what policy may be,
a lord of London say, one of the three.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And you (Sir boy) for pomp perform the like,To wealth.
Bid him that dare this impreze batter once,
Be well advised he be no beggar's brat,
Nor base of courage, nor of bad conceit:
To match himself with such magnificence,
As fits lord pomp of London for his love:
Call if he come that can encounter me,
Or move me not for each envious swad.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Will, be not wanton nor of wayward mood,To Will.
Wait as do these, use faith and diligence,
And mark him well that dare disdain this shield,
Which London's lord that pleasure hath to name,
Hath here advanced in honour of his dame.
I bid thee mark him well, whate'er he be,
That London's pleasure doth in malice scorn,
For he's a rascal, or a stranger born.
Good boy mark well his gesture and his look,
His eye, his gate, his weapon and attire,
And dog him to his lodging, or his den,
For I will make him scum and scorn of men,
No better boy than Will, when Will is pleased,
Be pleased my boy, and so be my good Will.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: And so good boys farewell, look to your charge,
Watch well good wit, who scorneth London's policy,
Be wary wit, for thou canst well discern.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Wealth watch for pomp for thou canst well defend

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Will can do something too when pleaseth him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will is a good boy where better is none. Exeunt the ●. Lordes.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nay wit were the best boy if will were gone.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Nay wealth is the best boy, sirs let that alone.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I wiss he saith true will, this wealth's a gay lad,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I care not for him, curmudgeonly swad.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Well, miss me a while and you'll go near to be sad.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will, ye are will fool, if of him ye be not glad.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nay wit if thou want him, thou'lt go near to be mad.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: To keep us still quiet, I would other talk we had,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I hope we'll not fall out being none but we three.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: If wealth were away, wit and will would agree.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nay, wit and will are at strife, when there's nobody but we.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Let pass, and of our shields (Sirs) let's make a little glee,

sp.speaker: Wil,
sp.p: What gives thy master here? A buzzard or a rite.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Wit, you show yourself a gentleman by g●ssing so right,
A buzzard? thou buzyard, wit, hast no more skill
Than take a falcon for a buzzard.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O be quiet good will:
It was but for sport, for I know the bird else,

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Thou mightest see it was no buzzard man by the bells:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What's the reason of this falcon, I pray thee will show.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Thou knowest that a falcon wares hie, and stoops low,
So doth pleasure.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And what's the word?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Pour temps, for time.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A very pretty one, I would it were in rhyme.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: In rhyme wit, why so?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Because it wants reason.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Look for my fist wit, if ye rap out such treason.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Treason, to what, boy?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: To my master's bird.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Now will my thumb wags, it was but to his word.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: 'Tis a pleasant gentleman, this young mast. Wit,
Your master hath something too, I pray ye what's it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Look will, and guess.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis a load in a shell.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: I had as lief ye had said, a frog in a well.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Is't not a great butterfly, Will, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: What is it in sadness?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A tortoise my boy, whose shell is so hard, that a loaden cart may go over and not break it, and so she is safe within, and wheresoever she goes, she bears it on her back, needing neither other succour or shelter but her shell: the word underneath her is providens securus, the provident is safe, like to the tortoise, armed with his own defence, and defended with his own armour: in shape somewhat round, signifying compass, wherein always the provident foresee to keep themselves within their own compass, my boy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wittily spoken, now wealth's mayst. hath got a daffadowndilly.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: If Will had not been wilful, now he might have said a lily, whose glory is without comparison, and beauty matchless. for Salomon the most sumptuous King that ever was, was never comparable in glory with the lily, neither is there any cities matchable with the pomp of London, mistake me not good boys, that this pomp tends to pride, yet London hath enough, but my lord pomp doth rightly represent the stately magnificence and sumptuous estate without pride or vain glory to London accommodate, and therefore the word is well applied to the impreze (Glory sans peer) for that the lily is neither proud of the beauty, nor vainglorious of the pomp: no more is London, but if it be joyful of any thing, it is of the peace and plenty, both flowing from two such fountains as becomes not us to name. Now therefore, my good boys, know that my master is rather magnificence than pomp in bad sense, and rather pomp than pride in the best sense.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And my lord is not pleasure sprung of voluptuousness, but of such honourable and honest kind conceit, as heaven and humanity well brooks and allows pleasure pleasing not pernicious.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Who would have thought that will had been philosophous, but what means the word pour temps in the shield, for time?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Wit, shall I call thee fool? the best pleasure of all lasts but a time,
For of all pleasures most pleasing to sight,
Methinks there is none to the falcon's high slight,
Yet diseases end it, the breach of a wing,
Nay, the breach of a feather spoils that sweet thing:

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: And so my master hath the vantage will ye or no, pomp and pleasure may be ill.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: May not policy be bad?

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Wit, well overtaken by Will that crafty lad.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A crafty goose, the gander gives him health,
Bad policy's seldom found in so christian a common wealth,
As London is I trust, where my master is a lord.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And ours so too.

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: Well, let us accord, for wit's a good thing, yet may be ill applied

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And so may wealth, be it employed in pride,
And will worst of all, when it disdains a guide.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A jackanapes hath wit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And so he hath will.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: But he never hath wealth: now ye are both still.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Yes, he wears a chain.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Well spoken, and like a bearward.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: If ye be non plus let the matter fall.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Wit, dost thou see? thus goes wealth away with all.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Let's reason no further for we shall have glee,
Here is a challenger to our shields, step we aside.

div.stage: Enter simplicity in bare black, like a poor citizen.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: He will eat them I think, for he gapes very wide.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Say nothing to him, and ye shall see the fool go by.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Sirrah, gape not so wide for fear of a fly.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Fly, flam flirt: why? Can a fly do hurt?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yea, have ye not heard that the fly hath her spleen
And the ant her gall?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: My uncle hath so I ween, for it's an angry old fellow
When his gall runs over: children good day,
Whose pretty lads are you three?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Three, are ye sure?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll not swear till I have told you: one, two, three.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I beshrew thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Me boy, why? I am beshrewed already, for I am married.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Then thou hast a wife?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yea, I would thou hadst her, if thou couldst stay her tongue,

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: I thy wise man? Why, I am too young.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And I am too old, but in good earnest good boys, be not angry,
That I call you boys, for ye are no men yet, ye have no beards
And yet I have seen boys angry for being called boys:
Forsooth they would be called youths: well, yet a boy is a boy
And a youth is a youth: well, if ye be not ashamed of the boy,
Good boys, whose eyes are ye?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No whit ashamed sir of that that we are, nor ashamed at all of those whom we serve, for boys we be, and as we be, we serve the three lords of London, to weet, policy, pomp, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A pretty spoken child and of a pretty wit.

sp.speaker: Wil
sp.p: Wit's his name indeed, are ye one of his godfathers, ye hit it so right?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: It is more than I know, then is thy name wit boy? Now of mine honesty welcome, for I have wanted thee a great while.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Welcome sir, how so? why do ye entertain me so kindly? I cannot dwell with you for I have a master already.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: So have I too, but she learns me little wit: my wife I mean well, all this while I stand here my wares are not abroad, and so I may lose both my customers and market.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: Wares sir, have ye wares? what wares do ye sell?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly child, I sell ballads: soft, whose wares are these that are up already? I paid rent for my standing, and other folks wares shall be placed afore mine, this is wise indeed.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: O, the fineness of the wares (Man) deserve to have good place.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They are fine indeed, who sells them, can ye tell? Is he free?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Our masters be, we wait on this ware, and yet we are no chapmen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Chapmen, no that's true, for you are no men, neither chapmen nor chopmen, nor chipmen nor shipmen, but if ye be chappers, choppers or chippers, ye are but chapboys, and chapboys ye are double.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Double, how is it? Teach me that and you will make me laugh a little.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: And me a little:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And me a little.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Then your three little laughs will make one great laugh:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: True, for if three fools were one fool, that were a great fool. But how are we double chapboys? Point to simplicity.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Because ye have two chaps, an upper chap and a nether chap.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: You said you would laugh but a little, but you laugh a great deal, why do ye laugh so much?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Because your wit was so great in expounding your meaning

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ye, you may see it is a good thing to have wit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: And what say you to wealth?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wealth? Marry wealth is better.

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And how say ye to will?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Indeed, good will is a great matter,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yea between a maid and a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why? you are not in love boy?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Yes but I am, and in charity too.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Charity? alas poor child, thou in charity, ha, ha, now must I laugh.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But you laugh a great while, and you laugh very loud,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Then I owe you nothing for laughing, and you hear me the the

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: But now laugh not we.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No, you may be maddle, coddle: well here's thrée passing fine lads, if a man were able to keep them all: let me see wealth, o that's a sweet lad: then wit, o that's a fine lad: Will, o that's a pretty lad. Will, wit, and wealth, God lend ye health. I would I could guile their masters of two of them. If I had fraud here that served lady Lucre, he would teach me: he would teach me to 'tice one of them from his master: which of them now, if a man should steal one? will? Nay, I care not for will outsep he be good will: wit, a pretty child, but a man can not live by wit: wealth, yea marry sir, I would I could win that wealth, for then I need neither will, nor wit, nor I need sell no ballads but live like a mouse in a mill and have another to grind my meal for me, I'll have a fling at one of them anon.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Do you not forget yourself gaffer.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Have you not wares to sell gaffer?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: When do you show gaffer?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well remembered pretty lads, ye may see, children can teach old folks, I am an unthrift indeed: well, my wares shall out now. But sir●, how sell ye your wares, how many of these for a groat?

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: Our wares are not to be sold.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not for silver nor gold? why hang they then in the open market?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: To be seen, not bought.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Then they are like ripe plums upon a rich man's tree that set men's tooth a watering when they be not to be bought: but what call ye these things?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Scutcheons.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Cushions, alas it were pity to sit on such fine cushions: but come my boys if you'll buy any of my wares, here's my stall, and I'll open and show straight.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: What dainty fine ballad have you now to be sold?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Marry child, I have chipping Norton a mile from chapel oath heath, a lamentable ballad of burning the Pope's dog: the sweet ballad of the Lincolnshire bagpipes, and Peggy and Willy, but now he is dead and gone: mine own sweet Willy is laid in his grave la, la, la, lan ti dan derry, dan da dan, lan ti dan, dan tan derry, dan do.

sp.speaker: Wit·
sp.p: It is a doleful discourse, and sung as dolefully.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, you can not mend it, can ye?

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: What will you lay on that? For I myself dare lay six groats to six of your bald ballads, that you yourself shall say I sing better than you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What a brag boy is this to comparison with a man, but boy boy, I will not lay six ballads to six groats, but I will lay six ballads to six jerks at your buttocks, that you shall not sing so well as I.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: That I shall not? No, possible you will not let me sing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I not let you? Is that spoken like wit? It is spoken like a woodcock, how can I stay thee if thou wilt sing out thy throat?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Well then, to our bargain, six ballads to six stripes, and who shall keep stakes?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Neither of your companions, for that's ask my fellow if I be a thief.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Will you keep the stakes yourself?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Best of all, for I mean plainly and will pay if I lose, here's my six ballads, they be ready: now how shall I come by your six stripes boy?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Down with your breeches, I'll fetch a rod and deliver them straight.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay then I care not if thou keep stakes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You speak too late gaffer, having challenged pre-eminence.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Then let's lay no wager but sing for good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Agreed, who shall begin?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O boy, who is the elder? Hast thou not heard give flounders to thy elder?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You mistake the fish, trust me I am sure 'tis give place, but begin with good grace.

div.stage: Here simp. sings first, and wit after, dialoguewise, both to music if ye will.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Now sirs, which sings best?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Tush, your copemates shall not judge: friend, what say you, which of us sings best?To one of the auditory.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: To say truth there's but had choice, how will you sell the ballad you sang, for I'll not buy the voice.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why wilt thou not buy my voice?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Because it will cost me more money to buy salad oil to keep it from rusting, than it is worth: but I pray ye honest man, what's this?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Read and then shalt see.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I cannot read.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not read and brought up in London, wru●st thou never to schols

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, but I would not learn.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou wast the more fool: if thou cannot read I'll tell this, this is Tarlton's picture: didst thou never know Tarlton ▪

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: No: what was that Tarlton? I never knew him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What was be: a prentice in his youth of this honourable city, God be with him: when he was young he was leaning to the trade that my wife useth now, and I have used, vide lice shirt, water-bearing: I wis he hath tossed a tankard in Cornhill ere now, if thou knewest him not I will not call thee ingram, but if thou knewest not him, thou knewest nobody : I warrant here's two crack-ropes knew him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I dwelled with him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Didst thou? now give me thy hand, I love thee the better.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: And I too sometime.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You child, did you dwell with him sometime?
Wit dwelled with him indeed, as appeared by his rhyme,

And served him well, and will was with him now and than, but soft, thy name is wealth, I think in earnest he was little acquainted with thee oh it was a fine fellow as ere was born, there will never come his like while the earth can corn. O passing fine Tarlton I would thou hadst lined yet.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: He might have some, but thou showest small wit, there is no such fineness in the picture that I see.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And thou art no cinque port man, thou art not wit free,
The fineness was within, for without he was plain,
But it was the merriest fellow and had such jests in store,
That if thou hadst seen him, thou wouldst have laughed thy heart sore.

sp.speaker: Weal,
sp.p: Because of thy praise, what's the price of the picture.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll tell thee my lad, come hither, if thou wilt be ruled by me thou shalt pay nothing, I'll give it thee, if thou wilt dwell with me, and I promise thee this counsel is for thy prefarming, hadst not thou better serve a free man of the city, and learn a trade to live another day, than to be a serving boy in thy youth and to have no occupation in thine age, I can make thee free if thou wilt be my prentice.

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: Why, wealth is free everywhere , what need I serve you●. My lord is a freeman if that may do me good.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I cry ye mercy m. boy, than your master is free of the lords company and you serve him that ye may be a lord when ye come out of your years.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Wealth is a proud boy, gaffer what say you to me?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thy name is wit, wilt thou dwell with me?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: If I like your name and science, perchance we'll agree

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Nay, my name and mine honesty is all one, it is well known he's a very fool that cannot beguile me, for my name is simplicity.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Coads gaffer were not you a mealman once and dwelled with lady Conscience?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yes, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: What, a better man?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No, for want of a better mistress, she was as very a fool as I we dwelled so long together that we went both on begging.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Indeed they that use a good conscience cannot suddenly be rich, but I'll not dwell with ye, you are too simple a master for me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nor I'll not dwell with you for all this world's treasure.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No, why whom serve you will?

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.p: I serve my lord pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And whom serve you wit?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I serve my lord policy

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: And whom serve you wealth?

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: I serve my lord pomp.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You should be served all with my lord Birchley if you were well served, these lads are so lordly that louts care not for them: for wealth serves pomp, wit serves policy, and will serves pleasure. wealth, will you buy this picture for your lord? Show Tarlton's picture,

sp.speaker: Wealth
sp.p: No, it's too hase a present for pomp.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And policy seldom regards such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Come on gaffer, come on, I must be your best chapman,
I'll buy it for pleasure, hold, there is a great:

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Gramercy good will, my wife shall love thee still,
And since I can neither get wit nor wealth,
Let my wife have her will, and let me have my health.
God forgive me, I think I never name her, but it conjures her, look
Where she comes, be mannerly boys that she knock ye not with her
Staff: keep your own counsel, and I'll make ye laugh.
What do ye lack, what lack ye.
Stand away these boys from my wares,
Get ye from my stall, or I'll wring you by the ears.
Let my customers see the wares: what lack ye what would ye have bought.

div.stage: Enter painful penury, attired like a water-bearing woman with her tankard.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: You have customers enough and if they were ought,
What do ye with these boys here to filch away your ware?
You show all your wit, you'll ne'er have more care.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Content ye good wife, we do not filch, but buy.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I meant not you, young master, god's blessing on your heart
You have bought indeed sir I see, for your part.
Be these two young gentlemen of your company,
Buy gentlemen, buy ballads to make your friends merry.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To stand long with your burden, methinks you should be weary

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: True gentlemen, but you may see poor painful penury
Is fain to carry thrée tankards for a penny.
But husband I say, come not home to dinner, its ember day,
You must eat nothing till night, but fast and pray.
I shall lose my draught at conduit, and therefore I'll away.
Young gentlemen God be with ye.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wife, must I not dine today?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: No sir by my say. Exit penury.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: If I must not eat, I mean to drink the more.
What I spare in bread, in ale I'll set on the score.
How say ye my lad? And do I not speak wisely?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Methinks ye do, and it's pretty, that simplicity
Hath gotten to his wife plain painful penury.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yea, I thank God though she be poor and scarce cleanly, yet she is homely, careful and comely.

div.stage: One call within. Wit, wealth and will, come to your lords quickly.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Must the scutcheons hang still?
One within. yea, let them alone.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Farewell master simplicity. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Farewell good m. boys e'en heartily, e'en heartily, heartily.
And hear ye will, I thank you for your handsel truly.
Pretty lads, hark ye sirs how? will, wit, wealth.

div.stage: Enter Wit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What's the matter you call us back so suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I forgotten to ask you whither your thrée lords of London be courtiers or cittiners?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Citizens born and courtiers brought up: is this all? Farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Citizens born and courtiers brought up, I think so, for they that be born in London are half courtiers before they see the court, for finesse and mannerliness o passing, my manners and misbehaviour is mended half in half since I gave over being a mealman and came to dwell in London: ye may see time doth much, time wears out iron horseshoes: time tears out millstones: time seasons a pudding well, and time hath made me a free man, as free to bear water and sell ballads, as the best of our copulation: I would have thought once my horse should have been free as soon as myself, and sooner too, for he would have stumbled with a sack of meal and lain along in the channel with it when he had done, and that some calls freedom, but it's but a dirty freedom, but ye may see, bad horses were but jades in those days: but soft, here comes customers: what lack ye, what is't ye lack, what lack ye? Come along and buy nothing: fine ballads, new ballads, what lack ye?

div.stage: Enter Nemo and the three lords.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: My lords come on, what suits have you to me?

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Renowned Nemo, the most only one
That draws no breath but of th'eternal air,
That knowest our suit before we bound to speak
For thou art the very oracle of thoughts:
Whose virtues do encompass thee about,
As th'air surrounds this massy globe of earth.
Who hast in power whatever pleaseth thee,
And canst bestow much more than we may crave,
To thee we seek, to thee on knees we sue,
That thou wilt deign from thraldom to release,
Those lovely dames, that London ladies are.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: What, those thrée caitiefs long ago condemned?
Love, Lucre, conscience, well deserving death,
Being corrupt with all contagion:
The spotted ladies of that stately town.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Love, Lucre, conscience we of thee desire,
Which in thyself hast all perfection,
Accomplished with all integrity:
And needest no help so do what pleaseth thee,
Who holdest fame and fortune both thy slaves,
And dost compel the destinies draw the coach:
To thee we sue, sith power thou hast thereto,
To set those ladies at their liberty.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: At liberty, thou spotless magistrate,
That of the cause dost carry all regard,
Careless of bribes, of birth and parentage,
Because thyself art only born to bliss,
Bless us so much that lords of London are,
That those thrée ladies born and bred with us
May by our suits, release of thraldom send.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Release my lords? why seek ye their release?
That have perpetual prison for their doom.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: But Nemo can from thence redeem them all.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Their deeds were cause, not Nemo of their thrall.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Yet Nemo was the judge that sentence gave.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: But Nemo never spilled, whom he could save:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Thou from perpetual prison mayst revoke.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Death hath no power 'gainst him to strike a stroke

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Thou only mild and courteous sir, vouchsafe
To grant our suit, and set those ladies free.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: What's your purpose in this earnest suit?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: To marry them, and make them honest wives.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: But may it be that men of your regard,
Lords of such fortune, and so famous place,
will link yourselves with ladies so forlorn,
And so distained with more than common crimes?

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Marriage doth make amends for many amiss.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: And love doth cover hears of cumbrous evils.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: And doth forget the faults that were before.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Mean as you say, ye need to say no more.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: In token that we mean what we have said,
Lo here our shields the prizes of our love:
To challenge all except thyself that dare
Deny those ladies to be ours by right.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Woo them and win them, win them and wear them too,
I shall both comfort and discourage you my lords,
The comfort's this, of all those former crimes
Wherewith the world was wont those dames to charge
I have them cleared and made them all as free
As they were born: no blemish left to see.
But the discourage (Gentle lords) is this,
The time of their endurance hath been long,
Whereby their clothes of cost and curious stuff
Are worn to rags, and give them much disgrace.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Alas good ladies, was there none that sued
For their release, before we took't in hand?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Yes, divers for fair lucre sought release,
And some for love would fain have paid the fees,
But silly conscience sat without regard,
In sorrow's dungeon, sighing by herself:
Which when I saw that some did sue for love,
And most for lucre, none for conscience:
A vow I made, which now I shall perform,
Till some should sue to have release for all,
Judged as they were, they should remain in thrall:
But you that crave their freedoms all at once
Shall have your suit, and see them here ere long,
A little while you must have patience,
And leave this place: go in my lords before.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Becometh us to wait on Nemo still,

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Not so: but lordings, the condition more
You promise me, sith they are in my power,
I shall dispose them when they are released
Upon you three, as I shall think it best.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Do but command and we shall all subscribe.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Then go your ways, for I have here to do. Exeunt 3. Lord
Sorrow draw near, tomorrow bring thou forth
Love, Lucre, conscience, whom thou hast in thrall,
Upon these stones to sit, and take the air,
But set no watch or espial what they do. Exeunt ambo.

div.stage: Enter Fraud, usury, dissimulation, simony and simplicity.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: How happy may we call this merry day my mates, wherein we meet, that once were desperate, I think, ever to have seen one another, when Nemo that upright judge had by imprisoning our mistresses, banished us (By setting such diligent watch for us) out of London, and almost out of the world. But live we yet? And are we met? and near our old seat? Usury is it thou? Let me see, or hath some other stolen thy face? Speakest thou man?

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.l: No fraud, though many have counterfeited both thee and me,
We are ourselves yet, and no changelings I see:
And why shouldst thou ask me man if I live:
The silly ass can not feed on harder forage than usury,
She upon thistles, and I upon a brown crust of a month old.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: So that usury and an ass are two of the profitablest beasts that a man can keep, yet th'one hath sharper teeth than th'other.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: But what means dissimulation? He droops methinks , what cheer man? Why cousin, frolic a fit, art thou not glad of this meeting? What's the cause of thy melancholy?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Not melancholic, but musing how it comes to pass that we are thus fortunate to meet as we do.

sp.speaker: Simony
sp.p: I'll tell thee why we met, because we are no mountains.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: But ye are as ill, for ye are monsters.

sp.speaker: Simony
sp.p: And men may meet though mountains cannot.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: In token that this meeting is joyful to us all,
Let us embrace altogether with heart's joy and affection.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: I see many of these old proverbs prove true, 'tis merry when knaves meet:

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: How sir, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If a man had a casting net, he might catch all you.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Art not thou simplicity?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.l: Goodman Simp. for I am married, and it like your mastership,
And you are mast. Fraud too, a pox on your worship.
I see, a fox and a false knave have all one luck, the better for banning,
And many of you crafty knaves live merrilier than we honest men.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.l: Sirrah, bridle your tongue if you'll be welcome to our company
No girds nor old grudges, but congratulate this meeting,
And sirs, if you say it, let's tell how we have lived since our parting.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: O it is great pity.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: What? to tell how we have lived:

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: No, that ye do live.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Yet again sirrah. Usury, as for thee it were folly to ask, for thou livest but too well, but dissimulation and simony, how have you two lived? discourse I pray you heartily.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Faith even like two mice in an aumbry that eat up all the meat, and when they have done, gnaw holes in the cupboard.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Fraud, after my scaping away at the sessions where I shifted as thou knowest in thrée sundry shapes, one of a friar, and they can dissemble: another like a woman, and they do little else: the third as a saint and a devil, and so is a woman. I was banished out of London by Nemo, to the country went I, amongst my old friends and never better loved than among the russet coats: once in a month I stole in other market day to leaden-hall and about, and sometime to Westminster hall. Now hearing some speech, that the ladies should be sued for, for I am come in hope of my old entertainment, supposing myself not known of many, and hoping the three lords will prevail in their suit, and I to serve one of them.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: He shall do well that gives thee a coat, but he should do better, that could take of thy skin.

sp.speaker: Simony
sp.p: And I have been a traveller abroad in other realms, for here I am so cried out against by preachers (And yet some ministers that be none, could be content to use me) that I was glad to be gone now in some other lands, and not very far off, I am secretly fostered, saving in Scotland, and the low countries, they are reformed, they can not abide me. Well now and then hither I came stealing over sea, and hearing as you here intend as you do.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: And for mine own part, amongst artificers and amongst a few bad conscienced lawyers, I have found such entertainment, as doth pass, yet would I with lucre fain be as I was.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Fraud is as ill as a cutpurse, by the mass.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: And for usury, the longer I live, the greater love I find yet would I be with lucre, again to please my mind.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Here's a good fellow too, one of our acquaintance, how hast thou lived simplicity?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: More honestly than all the rest of thy company: for when I might beg no longer, as begging was but bad, for you cozened me once of an alms, I fell to tankard bearing ▪ and so ●os a wife of the same science. painful penury, then got I my freedom, and feeling my shoulder grow weary of the tankard, set up an easier trade to sell ballads.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Hadst thou a stock to set up withal?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Wise enough to tell you, ay, and yonder's my stal, but beware I lose nothing, for if I do, I'll lay it straight to some of you, for I saw none so like thieves I promise you, since I set up.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Ye are a wiseman when your nose is in the cup, but soft who comes here? step we close aside, for these be the three ladies for my life brought out of prison by their keeper, let us be whist and we shall hear and see all, sirrah you must say nothing.

div.stage: Enter sorrow and the three ladies, he sets them on three stones on the stage.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Not till ye speak for I am afraid of him that's with thewoman ▪

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: O sorrow when? when sorrow wilt thou cease
To blow the spark that burns my troubled soul?
To feed the worm that stings my fainting breast,
And sharp the steel that gores my dying heart?
My thoughts are thorns, my tears hot drops of lead,
I plain, I pine, I die, yet never dead.
If world would end, my woe should but begin,
Lo, this the case of conscience for her sin:
And sin the food wherewith my worm was fed,
That stings me now to death, yet never dead.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Yet never dead, and yet love doth not th●●,
Love that to loss in life her folly lent,
Folly the food whereon her frailty fed,
Frailty the milk that nature's breast did give,
life, loss and folly, frailty, food and kind,
Worm, sting, thorns, fire and torment to the mind,
Life but a breath, and folly but a flower,
Frailty clay, dust the food, that fancy scorns,
Love a sweet bait to cover losses sour.
Flesh breeds the fire that kindles lustful thorns,
Lust, fire, bait, scorn, dust, flower, and feeble breath
Die, quench, deceive, fly, fade, and yield to death,
To death? O good, if death might finish all,
We die each day, and yet for death we call.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: For death we call, yet death is still in sight,
Lucre doth sealed in drops of melting gold,
Accusing rust, calls on eternal might,
Where flames consume, and yet we freeze with cold:
Sorrow adds sulphur unto fury's heat,
And chops them ye, whose chattering teeth do beat,
But sulphur, snow, flame, frost nor hideous crying
Can cause them die, that ever are in dying.
Nor make the pain diminish or increase,
Sorrow is slack, and yet will never cease.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: When sorrow ceaseth, Shame shall then begin,
With those that wallow senseless in their sin:
But ladies I have drawn you from my den,
To open air to mitigate some moan.
Conscience, sit down upon that sweating stone,
And let that flint (Love) serve thee for a seat,
And lady lucre, on that stone rest you.
And ladies thus I leave you here alone,
Mourn ye, but moan not, I shall absent be,
Yet good it were sometime to think on me.Exit

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Comfort it is to think on sorrow past.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sorrow remains when joy is but a blast.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A blast of wind is world's felicity,

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: A blasting wind and full of misery.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O conscience, thou hast most tormented me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Me hath thy worm oh conscience, stung too deep.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: But more myself my thoughts tormented have
Than both of you in sorrows sullen cave.
From whence drawn forth I find but little rest,
A seat uneasy, wet, and scalding hot,
On this hard stone hath sorrow me assigned,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: And on my seat myself I frozen find.
No flint more hard, no ice more cold than this.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: I think my seat some mineral stone to be.
I could from it, it draws heat from me.
Lady's consent, and we our seats will view.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Dare we for shame our stained faces show.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: My double face is single grown again.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: My spots are gone, my skin is smooth and plain.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: Doff we our veils and greet this gladsome light.
The chaser of glome sorrows heavy might.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Haile cheerful air and clearest crystal sky.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Haile shining sun and fairest firmament,
Comfort to those that time in woe have spent.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Upon my weeping stone is set remorse in brazen letters.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And on this flint in lead is charity.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: In golden letters on my stone is care.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Then lucre fits upon the stone of care.

sp.speaker: Lucre,
sp.p: And conscience on the marble of remorse,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Love on the flint of frozen charity,
Ladies alas, what tattered souls are we?

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Sorrow our hearts, and time our clothes hath torn

sp.speaker: Lucre,
sp.l: Then sit we down like silly souls forlorn,
And hide our faces that we be not known,
For sorrow's plagues tormented me no more,
Than will their fight that knew me heretofore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Then will their sight that knew us heretofore
Draw ruth and help from them for our relief:

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: For our relief? for conscience and for love,
No help, small ruth that our distress may move:

sp.speaker: Love,
sp.l: O conscience thou wouldst lead me to despair,
But that I see the way to hope is fair,
And hope to heaven directs a ready way,
And heaven to help is pressed, to them that pray.

sp.speaker: Lucre,
sp.l: That pray with faith, and with unfeigned remorse
For true belief and tears make prayer of force:

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Then ●eile ourselves, and silent let us stay, till heavens shall please to send some friends this way:Sit all dow●

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.l: Ladies unmasked, blush not for base attire,
Here are none but friends and servants all, dear lady lucre,
Dearer unto us than daily breath we draw from sweetest air;
Dearer than life, dearer than heaven itself,
Deign to discover those alluring lamps,
Those lovely eyes more clear than Venus' star,
Whose bright aspects worlds wonder do produce,
Unveil I say that, beauty more divine,
Than nature (Save in thee) did ever paint:
That we sworn slaves unto our mistress, may
Once more behold those stately lovely looks,
And do those duties which us well beseems,
Such duties as we all desire to do.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: I know that tongue Lucre, beware of fraud.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Of fraud? Indeed by speech it should be he. Fra. what seekest thou

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Lucre, to honour thee with wit, with worth, with life, with all I have, to be thy servant as I was before, to get thee clothes, and what thou wantest else.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: No fraud, farewell, I must be won no more, to keep such servants as I kept before.

sp.speaker: Simo.
sp.p: Sweet lady Lucre, me thou mayest accept.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: How art thou called?

sp.speaker: Simo.
sp.p: Simon.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: I? No, sir, conscience saith.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: No lucre, now beware, false not thy faith,
For simony's subject to perpetual curse.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: As you two have sped, I would desire to speed no worse,

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Make you a suit, you may chance to speed better:

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Not I, for of all, my tongue is best known,
But if I speak, it shall be to her that was once mine own:
Good lady love, thou little knowest the grief
That I thy friend sustain for thy distress,
And less believest what care I have of thee:
Look up good love, and to supply thy wants,
Ask what thou wilt, and thou shalt have of me,
Of me that joy more in thy liberty,
than in this life our light that comforts me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O gall in honey, serpent in the grass,
Oh bifold fountain of two bitter streams,
Dissimulation fed with viper's flesh,
Whose words are oiled, whose deeds the darts of death:
Thy tongue I know, that tongue that me be guiled,
Thyself a devil, madest me a monster vild.
From thee well known, well may I bless myself,
Dear bought repentance bids me shun thy snare.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: O happy love, if now thou can beware.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Marry, but hear ye motley-beard, I think this blindfold buzzardly hedge-wench spoke to ye, she knows ye though she see ye not, hark ye, you women, if you'll go to the alehouse, I'll bestow two pots on ye, and we'll get a pair of cards and some company, and win twenty pots more, for you play the best at a game called smelling of the four knaves that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Four? soft, yet they have not smelled thee.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: No, I am one more than is in the deck, but you'll be smelled as soon as ye begin to speak, I'll see what they'll say to me: hear ye you women, wives, widows, maids, men's daughters, what shall I call ye? these four fellows (Hark ye, shall I call ye crafty knaves) make me believe that you are the three that were the three fair ladies of London.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Gentle simplicity we are unhappy they.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Now ye bad fellows, which of ye had such a word as gentle fir● ▪

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Bad fellows ye rascal? If ere you bring me pawn I'll pinch ye for that word.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I cry you mercy m. injury, m. usury I meant not you,

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: If you mean us, we may be even with ye too.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Tut, I knew you an ostler, and a thief beside, you have rubbed my horse heels ere now for all your pri●e: but ladies, if ye be the thrée ladies, which of ye dwelled in Kent street? one of ye did, but I know not which is she, ye look all so like broom-wenches, I was once her servant, I'll ne'er be ashamed of her though I be rich, and I she be poor, yet if she that hath been my dame, or he that hath been my master come in place, I'll speak to them sure, I'll do my duty, which is lady Consc?

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Even I am she simplicity.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
I am glad ye are out of prison, I thought ye had forgotten me,
I went a-begging from you till the beadles snapped me up, now I am free and keep a stall of ballads, I may buy and sell, I would you had as good a gown now as I carried once of yours to pawn to usury here.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Gramercy good ●imp wilt thou be with me now?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: No I thank you heartily, I'll beg no more, I can not be with ye though I would for I am married to painful penury: look now my proud stately masters, I may if I will, and you would if ye might.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: No, not dwell with such a beggar as conscience.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: No, fraud ne'er loved conscience since he was an ostler.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Who cares for conscience but dies a beggar?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: That will not usury do, he will first take 3. score pound in the hundred.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Love, look on me and I will give thee clothes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I will no more by thee be so disguised.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Ye do the wiser, for his face looks like a cloakback:

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: In thy affections I had once a place:

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Those fond affections wrought me soul disgrace,

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: I'll make amends, if ought amiss were done:

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Who once are burned, the fire will ever shun.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: And yet once burned to warm again may prove:

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not at thy fire, I will be perfect love?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.l: I promise you the wenches have learned to answer wittily,
Here's many fair proffers to lucre, and love,
But who clothes poor conscience, she may sit long enough.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: I will clothe her straight:Usury takes fraud's cloak, and casts it on Cons

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.l: Will you master usury, that's honestly spoken.
Ha, that's no gramercy to clothe her with another man's cloak,
But I see you have a craft in the doing m. usury,
Usury covers conscience with fraud's cloak very cunningly.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: Alas who loads my shoulders with this heavy weed,
Fie, how it stinks, this is perfumed indeed,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Marry geppe goody conscience, indeed I do you wrong,
But I'll quickly right it, my cloak shall not cumber you long.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.l: All this while lucre knows not I am here,
But now will I to her, mark how I speed.
Lady the fairest that nature ever formed,
Lodestone of love, that draws affections darts.
The only object to all human eyes,
and sole destred dainty of the world,
Thy vassal here, a virtue in thy need
Whom thou by licence of the law mayst use,
Tenders himself, and all his services
To do thy will in duty as to fore,
Glad of thy freedom as his proper life.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Lady Lucre, you love an apple, take heed the caterpillar consume not your fruit.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Why who is it that maketh this latest suit?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: 'Tis usury. Aloud in her ear.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Great is the service he hath done for me,
But usury now I may not deal with thee.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: The law allows me madam, in some sort.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: But God and I would have thy bounds cut short.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.l: For you I reck not, but if God me hate,
Why doth the law allow me in some rate?

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: Usury slanders both law and state,
The law allows not though it tolerate,
And thou art sure be shut out at heaven gate.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: You were ever nice, no matter what you pra●e:

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Then it will be with him as it is at a great man's house in dinner time: he that knocks when the door is shut comes too late,

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Well usury, fraud, and simony
Dissimulation hearken unto me,
My tongue (Although in memory it be green)
Cannot declare what horrors I have seen,
He can it enter into mortal ears
Unmortified: the furies, fires and fears.
The shrieks, the groans, the tortures and the pains,
That any soul for each of you sustains.
No pen can write, how conscience hath me scourged.
When with your faults my soul she ever urged:
Arithmetic doth fail to number all,
The plagues of sorrow in the den of thrall:
Then tempt me not, nor trouble me no more,
I must not use you as I did before,
If you be found within fair London's gate.
You must to prison, whence we came of late.
Conscience will accuse ye if ye be in sight.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: That scurvy conscience works us all the spite:

div.stage: Enter Nemo,

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Well lucre, yet in thee we have delight.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Yonder come some, we must take our flight. Exeunt omnes

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Birds of a feather will fly together, but when they be taken then are they baken, yonder comes a customer, I'll to my stall:
Love, Lucre, and conscience, blindman buff to you all.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Conscience, love, Lucre, ladies all what cheer?
How do ye like the seats you sit upon.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: O pure unspotted Nemo sole paragon,
Of love, of conscience and perfection,
The marble of remorse I sit upon
Sweats scalding drops, like bitter brinish tears.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: So should remorse when conscience feels her gilt
But gentle love how feelest thou thy flint?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O sharp and cold, I freeze unto my seat,
The flint holds fire, and yet I feel no heat,
But am benumbed and frozen every joint.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: O love, so cold is charity in these times:
Lucre, how sit you?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Upon a heavy stone, not half so cold, not half so hot as theirs,
But of some secret power, for I do find and sensibly I feel,
That I from it exhale an earthly cold,
And it from me doth draw a kindly heat.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Such force hath care of lucre in itself,
To cool the heart and draw the vital spirits,
And such the true condition of you thrée:
Remorse of conscience, charity of love,
And care of lucre, such your uses be:
But ladies now your sorrow lay aside,
Frolic fair dames, an unexpected good
Is imminent through me unto you all:
Thrée lords there be your native countrymen,
In London bred, as you yourselves have been.
Which covet you for honourable wives,
And presently will come to visit you,
be not abashed at your base attire,
I shall provide you friends to deck you all.
If I command, stand up, else sit you still. Enter the 3. Lords.
Lo, where they come: my lords the dames be here.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Why are they wimpled? shall they not unmask theme

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: It is for your sake, for policy they do it:

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Much may their fortune and their feature be.
But what it is we cannot thus discern.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: You shall in time lord pomp, be yet consent.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Their same is more than cause or reason would,
May one of these be pleasures paragon?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Pleasure, be pleased and use no prejudice.
Madames stand up, mislike not their attire,
That shall be mended as your selved desire.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Their port, and their proportion well contented.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Right stately dames, if they were well attired:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: May we not see their beauty what it is?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Yes lordings yes, lucre, lift up thy veil.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Of beauty excellent.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Of rare perfection.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: A dainty face.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Unmask love.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Sweet love indeed.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: A lovely face.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: A gallant grace.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Conscience, uncover.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Beauty divine.

sp.speaker: Pom
sp.p: A face angelical.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Sweet creature of the world.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Enough for once, ladies sit down again:
As cunning chapmen do by curious wares,To the audience
Which seldom shown do most inflame the mind,
So must I deal, being dainty of these dames,
Who seldom seen shall best allure these lords:
A while my lords, I leave you with these thrée,
Converse, confer on good conditions,
I will right soon return with such good friends
As it concerns to clothe these dainty ones
if any in my absence visit them,
Know their intent, and use your skill therein.Exit

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Ladies, to call to mind your former lives
Were to recount your sorrows on a row,
Omitting then what you have been or be,
What you may be I'll speak, so it please you,
Wives to us thrée, ladies to London lords,
Pomp, pleasure policy, men of such regard,
As shall you guard from evil, once matched with us,
And policy presents this good to you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: With London's pomp may one of you be joined,
Possessing more than fortune can afford,
Fortune's a fool, but heavenly providence
Guards London's pomp, and her that shall be his:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: And London's pleasure, peerless in delights,
Will deign to make one of these dames his own,
Who may with him in more contentment live,
Than ever did the Queen of Aethiop.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: Though silence lords, our modesty enforce,
Nemo can tell the secrets of our thoughts,
Nemo that women's minds can constant keep,
He shall for us you answer good my lords,
I speak for all, though ill beseeming me. Enter falsehood and doub. dealing

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: You speak but well: my lord's step we aside
To note these fellows, what they do intend.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Nemo can tell, for he doth follow them. Enter Nemo.

sp.speaker: Falsehood
sp.l: Ladies to you, to some of you, we come,
Sent from such friends as much affect your good,
With garments, and with compliments of cost
Accordant well to dames of such degree: I come to lucre.

sp.speaker: D. dea.
sp.l: I to love am sent with no less cost than could be got for coin
Which with my message I deliver would,
Could I discern which of these dames were she,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Friend, I am love, what bringest thou there to me?

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Beware good love, from whom and what thou takest.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: No whispering friend, but show it openly,
The matter good, you need not be ashamed:
from whom comest thou?

sp.speaker: D. dea.
sp.p: That I conceal from any but from love,

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: From whom come you sir?

sp.speaker: Falsehood
sp.p: That shall lucre know, and none but she.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Then speak aloud, for whispering here is barred.

sp.speaker: Falsehood
sp.p: Then neither will I do nor speak at all.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Then I will speak and tell what you are both,
Thyself art falsehood, and art sent from fraud,
To compass lucre with a cloak of craft,
With lawn of lies, and call of golden guile.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Pack you my friend, for if you stay a while
You shall return no more to him that sent you.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Thou from dissimulation art sent,
And bringest a gown of glozing, lived wish lust,
A vardingale of vain boast, and fan of flattery,
A ruff of riot, and a cap of pride,
And double dealing is thy name and office both.

sp.speaker: D. dea.
sp.p: Falsehood, let's go, we are deciphered.

sp.speaker: Falsehood
sp.p: Lucre, thou losest here a princely gift. Exeunt ambo

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Lucre censumes being won by fraud or shift,
Thus lords you see how these are qualified,
And how these ladies shun that sharp rebuke,
Which some deserve by taking of such toys,
As women weak are tempted soon with gifts,
But here they come that must these ladies deck.
Lucre, arise, come from the stone of care:

div.stage: Enter honest industry, pure zeal, and sincerity.

sp.speaker: Ho. Indust.
sp.l: Fair lucre, lo what honest industry
To thee hath brought, to deck thy dainty self,
Lucre by honest industry achieved
Shall prosper, flourish, and continue long,Exit Lucre with ho. Industrie.
Come to thy chamber to attire thee there.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Thou mayest depart with honest industry.

sp.speaker: P. zeal.
sp.l: And love arise from charity's cold flint,
Pure zeal hath purchased robes to cover love,
Whiles love is single, zeal shall her attire
With kind affection, mortifying lust,
come love with me these garments to put on:

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Love, follow zeal and take his ornaments. Exit love with p. zeal

sp.speaker: Sincerity
sp.l: Rise conscience from that marble of remorse,
That weeping stone that scalds thy parched skin,
Sincerity such robes for thee hath brought,
As best beseems good conscience to adorn:
Come follow, that thou mayst go put them on,
For conscience clothed by sincerity,
Is armed well against the enemy.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Follow him Consc. fear not, thou art right. Exit Con. with Si●

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Most reverend Nemo thanks for this good sight, lucre is clothed by honest industry.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Love by pure zeal.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: And conscience by sincerity.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Lordings, thus have you seen them at the first,
And thus you see them, trust me, at the worst,
Depart we now, come hence a day or two,
And see them decked as dainty ladies should,
And make such choice as may content you all.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Thanks righteous Nemo we the London lords
Only to thee ourselves acknowledge bound. Exeunt omnes

div.stage: Enter painful penury and simplicity.

sp.speaker: Penury
sp.p: Come on gentle husband, let us lay our heads together, our purses together, and our reckonings together, to see whether we win or lose, thrive or not, go forward or backward, do you keep a book or a score?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A score wife? you mean for the alehouse, do you not? I would have her examine me thereof no further, for I am in too far there, more than I would she should know.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I mean no alehouse score, but a note of your wares, let me see, first you began to set up with a royal, how much money have ye? what ware, and what gain?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I have five shillings in money, two shillings in wares, or thereabouts, and I owe two shillings and eight pence upon the score, how much is that? five shillings, two shillings, and two shillings and eight pence.

sp.speaker: Penury
sp.p:
That is nine shillings and eight pence, so we are worse by a
a groat then when we began, well once again I'll set ye up, here is four groats I have got by bearing water this week, make up your stock, and run no more behind ▪ who comes here?

div.stage: Enter fraud like an artificer.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: What lack ye? What do ye lack?

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Me lacke da moons pour de frene very seen Franche knack da feene gold buttoone, de brave bugla lace, a da feene gold ring, you be free man, me un 'Fortiner, you buy a me beware, you gain ten pound by lay out ten shelleng●.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wife, what hard luck have we that cannot make x. shillings now to gain x. pound: why, x. pound would set us up for ever.

sp.speaker: Penury
sp.p: Husband see the ware, and if ten shilling will buy it, it shall go hard but we will make that money: friend, show my husband your wares

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Look you dear mastra de seen button de la gold, de ring de gold, de bugla sheane, two shelleng une dozen de button, une shellinga une ring, 'tis worth x, shelleng, but mastra and matressa me mussa make money to go over in my own country, but me loose teen● pound pour haste to go next tide or tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Penury
sp.p: Here is five shillings buy them of this stranger.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Friend you have not stolen them, but you make them, well, I'll buy them i'the open market, and then I care not, here is ten shillings, deliver me the wares.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Dear mastra, o pouer necessity maka me selpour grand, grand loss, you shall gein x. pound at least, gour boy.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Mechant, I think I am even with ye now for calling me ostler, you'll thrive well with such bargains, if ye buy, ye know not what, fraud hath fitted ye with worse than your ballads.

sp.speaker: Penury
sp.p: You'll warrant them gold sirrah,

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: We, so good goll as you pay for: adieu monster. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Adieu monster: adieu fool, sell such gold buttons and rings for so little money, good lord what pennyworths these strangers can afford: now wife let me see, x. pound, when we have ten pound, we'll have a large shop, and sell all manner of wares, and buy more of these, and get ten pound more, and then ten pound, and ten pound, and twenty pound, than thou shalt have a taffeta hat and a guarded gown, and I a gown and a new cap, and a stik doublet, and a fair house.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I thank ye husband, well, till then look well to your wares, and I'll ply my water-bearing and save and get, and get and save till we be rich, but bring these wares home every night with ye:

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Tush, I shall sell them afore night for ten pound, go wife, go, I may tell you I am glad this French fellow came with these wares, we had fallen to eramining the ale-score else, and then we had fallen cut, and the ale wife and my wife had scolded: well, a man may see, he that's ordained to be rich, shall be rich: go woman.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Nemo and the three lords, as though they had been chiding.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: From whence good lords grew this hot argument?

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Thou knowest already, yet if thou wilt hear,
For this we strive: fond pleasure makes account
Summing his bills without an auditory,
That lady Lucre ought of right be his.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: So I affirm, and so I will maintain
That lady Lucre ought of right be his.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: So I affirm, and so I will maintain
That pleasure ought by right dame Lucre have,
To bear the charge of sports and of delights.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Nay to support the haughty magnificence
And lordly pomp of London's excellence,
Befits it rather lucre join with me,
By whom her honour shall be most advanced.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: More fit for pomp than pleasure, but most fit
That policy with lucre should be matched,
As guerdon of my studies and my cares
And high employments in the common wealth:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: What pleasure can be fostered without cost:

sp.speaker: Pom,
sp.p: What pomp or port without respect of gaine●

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: What policy without preferment lives?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Pleasure must have lucre:

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Pomp hath need of lucre:

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Policy merits lucre:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Pleasure dies without lucre,

sp.speaker: Pom,
sp.p: Pomp decays without lucre,

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Policy droops without lucre:

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Thus lords you show your imperfections:
subject to passions, straining honours bounds,
Be well advised, you promised to be ruled,
And have those dames, by me disposed to you,
But since I see that human humours oft
Makes men forgetful of their greater good.
Be here a while, dame lucre shall be brought
By me, to choose which lord she liketh best,
So you allow her choice with patience. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Go, we abide thy doom till thy return,

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: If lucre be not mad she will be mine,

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: If she regard her good she will be mine.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: If she love happy life, she will be mine,
Women love pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Women love pomp.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Women use policy: and here she comes that must decide the doubt.

div.stage: Enter Nemo with conscience all in white.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Conscience content thee with a quaint conceit,
Conceal thy name to work a special good,
Thou art not known to any of these lords,
By face or feature, till they hear thy name,
Which must be lucre for a fine device,
And conscience clear indeed's the greatest gain,
Lo, lordings here fair lucre whom ye love:
Lucre, the choice is left unto thyself,
Which of these three thou wilt for husband choose.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: The modesty that doth our sex beseem
Forbids my tongue therein to tell my thought,
But may it please my lords to pardon me,
Which of you three shall deign to make such choice,
Him shall I answer to his own content,

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: If lucre please to match with policy,
She shall be mistress over many men.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: If lucre like to match with London's pomp,
In stately port all others she shall pass.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: If pleasure may for wife fair lucre gain,
Her life shall be an earthly paradise.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Lo, lucre, men, and port, and pleasant life
Are here propounded, which wilt thou accept?

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: Lord policy, love were the only choice
Methinks for you, that all your cares employ
And studies for the love of common wealth,
For you lord pleasure, conscience were a wife,
To measure your delights by reason's rule,
In recreation conscience help to use.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Were conscience half so sweet as is thyself,
Her would I seek with suits and services.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: No less accomplished in perfection
Is conscience, than this lady I protest,

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: But on this dame hath pleasure fixed his heart,
And this or death the period of his love.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Lucre with pomp most aptly might combine

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Lucre, or love if case thou wilt be mine,
Let pass thy name, thyself do I desire,
Thee will I have except thyself deny,
With thee to live ▪ or else for thee to die.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: What if I deny?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Then will I have her.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: If we deny?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: So much the rather.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: The rather in despight of us? Not so.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: My lords, no quarrel, let this lady go,
And if ye trust me. I'll content ye both,
Pleasure, this is not lucre:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: She's lucre unto me: but be she love or conscience, this is she.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Whom you will, have?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Spite of the devil, I will.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Must it not be my lord if I agree?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Agree.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Some further proof it fits of you to see:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Receive a pawn, my heart, my hand, and oath,
To be thy own in love, in faith, and troth.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Thus you are fast, and yet myself am free:

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: I know in ruth thou wilt me not refuse:

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: I know not that, but other I'll not choose.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: It is enough, lord pleasure, do not fear,
Conscience will use you as becomes her best.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: And art thou conscience? welcomer to me than either love or lucre,

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: God send grace I be,

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: My lords be pleased, ere long shall you be sped,
As much to your contents as pleasure is,
Say but the word ▪ myself shall soon present
Lucre and love, well worthy such as you.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Right thankfully those favours we'll receive,

div.stage: Enter Diligence, in haste

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: My lords, if your affairs in present be not great
Greater than any, save regard of life,
Yea even the greatest of the common wealth,
Prepare ye to withstand a stratagem,
Such as this land nor London ever knew.
The Spanish forces lordings are prepared,
In bravery and boast, beyond all bounds
T'invade, to win, to conquer all this land.
They chiefly aim at London's stately pomp,
At London's pleasure, wealth and policy.
Intending to despoil her of them all,
And over all those lovely ladies three.
Love, lucre, conscience, peerless of the rarest price.
To tyrannize and carry hardest hand.
From Spain they come with engine and intent
To slay, subdue, to triumph and torment:
Myself (So heaven would) espial of them had,
And diligence, dear lords, they call my name.
If you vouchsafe to credit my report,
You do me right, and to yourselves no wrong,
Provided, that you arm you, being warned.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Diligence, thy service shall be known,
And well rewarded: Nemo, for a time
Conceal this dame, and live secure unseen,
Let us alone whom most it doth concern,
To meet and match our ever weening foes.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Nemo keep close, and conscience pray for us.
been gone and recommend us to our god.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: My lords, if ever, show your honours now,
Those proud usurping Spanish tyrants come,
To reave from you what you do most regard,
To take away your credit and your fame.
To race and spoil our right renowned town:
And if you love or lucre do regard,
Or have of conscience any kind of care,
The world shall witness by this action,
And of the love that you to us pretend,
In this, your valour shall assurance give:
More would I speak, but danger's in delay,
You know my mind, and heavens record my thoughts,
When I with prayers for you will penetrate,
And will in heart be present in your fight:
Now pleasure, show what you will do for me.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: I will be turned to pain for thy sweet sake.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Fair conscience fear not, but assure thyself
What kind affection we soever bear
To love and lucre, in this action
Chiefly for thee our service shall be done.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: For conscience' sake more than for lucre now,

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: For love and conscience, not despising lucre.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Only for conscience will I hazard all.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: And I from hence will her convey a space,
Till you return with happy victory. Exeunt ne. And Con.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Farewell my lords, for me my lords, for me.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Diligence, what number may there be?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: A mighty host, and chiefly led by three,
Who brave it out in show, as men assured
Of victory, sans venture, or repulse.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: How near be they?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: So near my lords, that each delay is death,
Stand on your guard, they come as challengers,
To bruise your shields, and bear away your prize,
Mounting the seas, and measuring the land
With strong imaginations of success,

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Well, diligence go get in readiness
men and munition, bid our pages ply
To see that all our furniture be well,
W●t, wealth and will to further wars be fit,Exit Dil●●.
My lords, I would I might advise ye now,
To carry as it were a careless regard,
Of these Castilians, and their accustomed bravado:
Lord pomp, let nothing that's magnifical,
Or that may tend to London's graceful state
Be unperformed. As shows and solemn feasts,
Watches in armour, triumphs, cresset-lightes,
Bonfires, bells, and peals of ordinance.
And pleasure, see that plays be published,
May-games and masks, with mirth and minstrelsy,
Pageants and school-feastes ▪ bears, and puppet plays,
Myself will muster upon Mile-end green,
As though we saw, and feared not to be seen:
Which will their spies in such a wonder set,
To see us reck so little such a foe,
Whom all the world admires, save only we:
And we respect our sport more than his spite,
That John the Spaniard will in rage run mad,
To see us bend like oaks with his vain breath.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: In this device such liking I conceive,
As London shall not lack what pomp can do,
And well I know that worthy citizens
Do carry minds so frank and bountiful,
As for their honour they will spare no cost:
Especially, to let their enemy know.
Honour in England, not in Spain doth grow.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: And for the time that they in pleasure spend,
'Tis limited to such an honest end,
Namely, for recreation of the mind,
With no great cost, yet liberal in that kind,
That pleasure vows with all delights he can
To do them good, till death to be their man.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Of policy they trial have at large:

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Then let us go and each man to his charge ▪

div.stage: Exeunt the three lords.
Enter simplicity led in by usury.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
