sp.p: Ay sir? Why alas I bought them of a stranger, an old French man for good gold, and to be worth ten pound, for so be told me, I have good witness, for my own wife was by, and lent me part of the money.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: And what did they cost you?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Ten shillings every penny.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: That argues you are guilty: why? could ye buy so many rings and buttons of gold think ye for ten shillings? Of whom did ye buy them?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Of an old French man, the old French disease take him.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: And where dwells that old French man?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: In France I think, for he told me he was to go over the next tide, or the next day, my wife can tell as well as I, if ye think I lie, for she was by.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: A good answer, he dwells in France and you dwell here, and for uttering copper for gold you are like to lose both your ears upon the pillory, and besides lose your freedom.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Nay, if I lose my ears, I care not for my freedom, keep you my freedom, so I may keep my ears, is there no remedy for this m. usury?

sp.speaker: Usury.
sp.p: None, except you can find out that old French man.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Peradventure I can, if you'll let me go into France to seek him:

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: So we may lose you, and never see him, nay that may not be.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: You have a good pawn there, good master usury be good unto me.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Nay, now I'll pinch ye, you villain, ye know how ye have ever used me, but now off goes your ears at least,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay ▪ good master usury take all my goods and let me go,

div.stage: Enter ●raud, dissimulation, simony in canvas coats like sailors.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: What's the matter usury, that this poor knave cries so:

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: O master fraud, speak to him to let me go:

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p:
Fraud? Ye villain, call me not by my name, and ye shall see I will speak to him to let ye go free: usury, of all old fellowship let this
poor knave pack, if the matter be not too heinous.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: No sir, his fault is odious, look here what stuff he would utter for gold, flat copper, and he saith, he bought them of an old Frenchman

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: But thou didst not sell them, didst thou?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No sir, I would have but laid them to pawn for five pounds to him.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: That was more than they be worth, I promise thee a foul matter, well, thou must lose thy ware and be glad to escape, so usury, at my request ye shall let the poor man go.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Well, for this once I will, sirrah, get ye packing, and take heed of such a piece of work again while ye live.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: There is divers pieces of work in that box, pray ye give me some of my goods again, a ring or something.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Not an inch, and be glad ye scape as ye do,

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Alas, I am undone, there's all the wealth and stock I have.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Do ye long to lose your ears, be gone ye foolish knave.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I thank ye master fraud: I'll not go so far, but I'll be near to hear and see what the meaning of these fellows in this canvas should be, for I know fraud, dissimulation, and simony to be those thrée: here I think I am unseen. Simplicity hides him near them.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Usury, thank me for this good booty, for it is I that holy ye to it, for I should them to him for gold indeed in the shape of an old French artificer, come give me half for I deserve it, for my part was the first beginning of this comedy, I was ever afraid, lest the fool should have known me, for ye see now though disguised, he calm by my name.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Did a so? I am glad I have found the French man, now I'll raise the street, but I'll have my wares again, and prove ye as ye were, ever both false knaves I believe. Exit sim.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Kill him, stab him, out villain, he will betray us all.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: What a fool were you to speak before he was gone, now you have lost your part of this too, for he will go complain, you will be sought for, and I made to restore these things again.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Not if thou be wise, thou wilt not tarry the reckoning, for seest thou not us three? Dissimulation simony and myself?

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Yes: what means these canvas suits? Will ye be sailors?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Usury make one, this is our intent: let's see that none hear
us now: the Spaniards are coming thou hearest with great power, here is no living for us in London, men are grown so full of conscience and religion, that fraud, dissimulation and simony are deciphered, and being deciphered are also despised: and therefore we will slip to the sea, and meet and join with the enemy, and if they conquer as they may, for they are a great army by report, our credit may rise again with them, if they fail and retire, we may either go with them and live in Spain, where we and such good fellows are tolerated and used, or come fitly again hither, so long as none knows but friends.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: But will you do thus you two?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: And thou too I hope, why, what should we do?

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Whatsoever ye do, be not traitors to your native country.

sp.speaker: Simo.
sp.p: 'Tis not our native country, thou knowest, I simony am a roman, dissimulation a mongrel, half an Italian, half a Dutchman fraud so too, half French, and half Scottish: and thy parents were both Jews, though thou wert born in London, and here usury thou art cried out against by the preachers: join with us man to better thy state, for in Spain preaching toucheth us not.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: To better my state, nay, to alter my state, for here where I am, I know the government, here can I live for all their threatening, if strangers prevail, I know not their laws nor their usage, they may been oppressor, and take all I have, and it is like they are so, for they seek that's not their own. Therefore here will I stay sure, to keep what I have, rather than be a traitor upon hap and had I wist: and stay you if ye be wise, and pray as I pray, that the preachers and all other good men may die, and then we shall flourish, but never trust to stranger's courtesy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: We shall trust but to our friends and kin, you'll not go with us, yet for old acquaintance keep counsel, betray us not, for we'll be gone to sea, I am afraid then foolish knave have belayed the streets for us.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Let me go afore ye, if any such thing be, I'll give ye inkling.Exit

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Do, farewell usury: and as he goes one way, we'll go another, follow sirs, never trust a shrinker, if he be your own brother. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter the three lords with their pages and fealty a Herald before them, his coat having the arms of London before. and an olive tree behind.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Fealty, thou faithful herald of our town,
Thou true truce-kéeper, and sure friend in peace,
Take down our shields, and give them to our boys:
Now fealty, prepare thy wits for war,He delivers them
To parley with the proud Castillians
Approaching fast the frontiers of our coast:
Wit, here, my page in every message shall
Attend on thee, to note them and their deeds:
I need not tell thee, they are poor and proud,
Vaunters, vainglorious, tyrants, truce-breakers,
Envious, ireful, and ambitious,
For thou hast found their facing and their brags,
Their backs, their coffers, and their wealth, their rag●,
But let me tell thee what we crave of thee,
To scan with judgement what their leaders be,
To note their presence and observe their grace,
And truly to advertise what they seem,
Whether to be experienced in arms,
Or men of name those three that led the rest,
The rest refer we to thy own conceit,

sp.speaker: Feal,
sp.p: I hope in this my duty to discharge, as heretofore

div.stage: Simplicity, make a great noise within, and enter with three or four weaponed.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Clubs, clubs, nay come neighbours come, for here they be, here I left them, arrant thieves, rogues, cozeners, I charge ye as you will answer, prebend them, for they have undone me, and robbed me, and made me the poorest free man that ever kept a ballad stall:

sp.speaker: A constable,
sp.p: I charge ye keep the peace and lay down your weapons:To the three lords.

sp.speaker: Pomp,
sp.p: Who raised this tumult? Speak, what means this stir?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: O I am undone, robbed, spoiled of all my stock, let me see, where be they? Keep every street and door, 'samine all that comes for fraud that cozener.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Masters, what mean you in these troublous times to keep this coil?

sp.speaker: Const,
sp.p: Alas my lord, here's a poor man robbed, or cozened.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: I am robbed oh my boys, my pretty boys, I am undone, saw ye no thieves, nor no crafty knaves, what be all these?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Simplicity, away, these be our lords, offend them not for fear.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: I seek not them, I seek for fraud that robbed me.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Go seek else where, for here's no place for such.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: My friends depart, and qualify this stir,
And see peace kept within the walls I charge ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I will my lord, come

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: We came too late to find your losses. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Pray for me my boys, I think I shall hang myself I come ever too late to speed.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Now lords, let honour's fire inflame on? thoughts,
And let us arm our courage with our cause,
And so dispose ourselves to welcome them,
Do me the favour (If I may entreat)
To be the first to front the foe in face,
The vanguard let be policies this once,
Pomps the main battle pleasures the rearward:
And so bestow us if you think it good.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I think it good, and time that it were done.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: I think it good, and wish the enemy come.

div.stage: Enter Diligence.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: And here they come, as brave as Philip's son,
And his Ephestion, wont to be arrayed
In glittering gold, and party coloured plumes,
With curious pendents on their lances exit,
Their shields impressed with gilt copertiments,
Their pages careless, playing at their backs,
As if with conquest they triumphing came.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: If they be conquered greater is their shame,
But diligence go post alongst the coast,
To tell the news, and look to welcome them,
Let us alone: my lords you hear the news,
More words were vain, I know ye well resolved. Exit Dil.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: And here they come, o proud Castillians.

div.stage: Enter first Shealty the herald: then pride, bearing his shield himself, his impreze, a peacock: the word, non par illi his page shame after him with a lance, having appendent gilt, with this word in it, sur lé ciel, ambition, his impreze, a black horse salliant, with one hinder foot upon the globe of the earth, one for● foot stretching towards the clouds, his word, non sufficit orbis: his page treachery after him, his pendent argent and azure, an armed a●me catching at the sun beams, the word in it, et gloriam phoebi. Last, tyranny, his impreze, a naked child on a spear's point bleeding, his word, pour sangue, his page, terror, his pendent ●uless, in it, a tiger's head out of a cloud, licking a bloody heart: the word in it, cura cruor. March once about the stage, then stand and view the lords of London, who shall march towards them, and they give back, then the lords of London wheel about to their standing, and th'other come again into their places, then policy sends fealty: their herraldes coat must have the arms of Spain before, and a burning ship behind.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: My lords, what mean these gallants to perform,
Come these Castilian cowards but to brave?
Do all these mountains move to breed a mouse?
Fealty, go fetch their answer resolute
How they dare be so bold, and what they dare do here.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: What wouldst thou herald? As feal is going towards them, they send forth Sheal.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Parley with those thrée, herald.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: They scorn to grace so mean a man as thou with parley or with presence.

sp.speaker: Fea:
sp.l: Do they scorn? what, are thy masters, monarchs every one?
Or be they gods? or rather be they devils?
Scorn they a herald's presence and his speech?
Name them, that I may know their mightiness,
And so avoid of duties some neglect.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: Monarchs in minds, and gods in high conceits,
That scorn you English, as the scum of men,
Whom I ne dare without their licence name,
Fore whom thy duties all are few and base,

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: Imperious Spaniard, do a herald right.
Thyself art one, their trowch man if thou be,
Be thou my trunk, that I my message may
Through thee convey to them from London lords.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: Base English groom, from beggars sent belike,
Who for their mate thee malapert account,
Dare I (Thinkst thou) these lords magnificent,
Without their special pleasure understood,
Once move with message, or with show of speech?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: More servile thou to lose a herald's due,
That is in field a King's companion,
But if thou dare not my ambassage do,
Stand by and stop not my access to them.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: Rather will I return and know their minds.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Now boy, what news. When Sheal goes to them, wit goes to the 3. Lords of lond.

sp.speaker: Wit,
sp.l: The fearful herald of yon famous crew
Durst not your message to his masters tell,
Till fealty with contumelious words,
(Yet was the Spaniard brave and hot in terms)
Enforced him for their answer resolute. The span. whisper with their her.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Which now belike our herald shall receive,
For theirs comes to him.

sp.speaker: Sheal.
sp.l: It pleaseth them to be magnifical,
And of their special graces to vouchsafe
And counterview of pages, and of shields.
A countermessage by us heralds done:
A favour which they seldom grant to foes,
Go thou for those, I meet thee will with these.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: My lords then braving Spaniards wish
A counterview of pages and of shields,
But what they mean or be I know not yet:
Haply you may by their ymprezes view,
Or I by parley some conjecture give,
So please it you your pages and your shields
With me to send, their herald comes with theirs.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Our shields I reck not, but to send our wealth

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.p: Accompanied with wit and will, no peril.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: It is my wealth, but keep him if they dare,
I'll fetch him double if they do my lords,

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Boys, take our shields and spears, for they come on.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vail Spaniard, couch thy lance and pendent both, knowest where thou art? Here will we bear no braves

div.stage: When the English boys meet the other, cause them to put down the tops of their lances, but they bear up theirs.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Down with your point, no loft born lances here
By any stranger be he foe or friend.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Well dost thou note the couching of thy lance,
Mine had ere this else gored your Spanish skin.

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.p: Well done my boys, but now all reverence.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: Advance again your lances now my boysHold up again

sp.speaker: S. pride.
sp.p: Dicito nobis ideo qui ades, quid sibi velint isthaec emblemata? Dicito (Inquam) lingua materna: nos enim omnes belle intelligimus, quamuis anglicè loqui dedignamur.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: Then know Castillian cavalieroes this,
The owners of these emblems are three lords
Those three that now are viewing of your shields,
Of London, our chief city are they lords,
Policy, pomp, and pleasure be their names:
And they in honour of their mistresses,
Love, Lucre, conscience, London ladies thrée,
Emblazoned these scutcheons, challenging
Whom durst compare, or challenge one of them,
And policy a tortoise hath impressed,
Encompassed with her shell, her native walls,
And providens securus is his word:
His page is wit, his mistress lady love.
Pomp in his shield a lily hath portrayed,
As paragon of beauty, and boon grace:
Glory sans peer his word, and true it is,
With London's pomp Castille cannot compare,
His page is wealth, his mistress lucre hight.
Pleasure, the dainty of that famous town,
A falcon hath emblazoned, soaring high,
To show the pitch that London's pleasure flies:
His word pour temps, yet never stoops to train,
But unto conscience, chosen for his dear.
His page is will, and thus th'effect you hear.

sp.speaker: S. pride.
sp.p: Buena bvena per los lutheranos angleses.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Mala, mala per catholicos castillianos.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Loqueris anglicè?

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: Maximè dominae.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Agedum, go too then and declare thy lords, their shields, their pages, and their purpose.
Speak man, fear not, though Spain use messengers ill,
'Tis England's guise to entreat them courteously.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: Three cavalieroes castillianos here,
Without compeers in compass of this world:
Are come to conquer, as full well they shall
This molehill isle, that little England hight,
With London that proud paltry market town,
And take those dame's love, Lucre, conscience
Prisoners, to use or force as pleaseth them.
The first (Now quake) is Spanish majesty,
That for his impreze gives Queen Juno's bird,
Whose train is spanged with Argus hundred eyes,
The Queen of gods scorns not to grace him so.
His word is non par illi, none his like:
Yet is his page or henchman modesty,
Lucre the lady that shall be his prize:
And in his pendent on his lances point,
Sur le ciel his word, above the heavens.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Whilom indeed above the heavens he was,
Could be have kept him in that blessed state,
From thence for pride he fell to pit of pain,
And is he now become the pride of Spain?
And so his page not modesty but shame.
Well, on the rest.

sp.speaker: Sheal.
sp.l: Don honour is the next grand peer of Spain,
Whose impreze is a courser salient.
Of colour sables, darkening air and earth,
Pressing the globe with his disdainful foot.
And sallying to aspire to rolling skies,
Non sufficit orbis is his haughty word,
The world sufficeth not high honour's thoughts,
and on the pendent fixed en his lance,
A hand is catching at the sunny beams:
Et gloriam phoebi, and the sun's bright coach.
Honour would guide, if he might have his will.
His page is action tempering still with state.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Himself ambition, whom the heavens do hate,

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: And love the lady that he hopes to gain,

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: His thoughts distract from foul distempered brain
Proves him the very firebrand of Spain:
And in his shield his black disordered beast,
Scaling the skies, scornful to tread the ground,
And both his words, proud words prove perfectly
Action his page to be but treachery,
Ever attendant on ambition: but to the third.

sp.speaker: Sheal.
sp.l: The third ground cavaliero is government,
Severe in justice, and in judgement deep:
His impreze is a naked infant gored
Upon a lance, signifying, severity.
His word, pour sangue, for blood of enemies
He bends his sources: on his pendent is
A lyger licking of a bleeding heart:
And cura cruor is the word thereon,
His care's for blood of those that dare resist:
Yet hight his page that follows him, regard,
And he for conscience to this conquest comes.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: The government of Spain is tyranny,
As do his impreze and his words declare,
His page is terror: for a tyrant fears
His death, in diet, in his bed, in sleep,
In conscience: spite the Spanish tyranny
Hath shed a sea of most unguilty blood: well, what's the end?

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: The end is best you yield, submitting you to mercy of these lords.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Before we fight? soft sic, ye brave too fast.
Castilians, know that Englishmen will knock, but say.
Doth Spanish pride for London's lucre gape,

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: And would their tyranny conscience captive have?

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Doth their ambition London's love affect?

sp.speaker: Sheal.
sp.l: All this they will, and pray upon your town,
and give your lands away before your face:
Alas, what's England to the power of Spain?
A molehill, to be placed where it pleaseth them.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: But in this molehill many pismires be,
All which will sting before they be removed,
What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Sheal.
sp.p: Shealty,

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: An Irish word, signifying liberty, rather remissness, looseness if ye will, why hath thy coat a burning ship behind?

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: To signify theburning of your fleet by us Castillians.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: It rather means your common wealth's on fire,
About your ears, and you were best look home,
A common wealth's compared to a ship,
If yours do flame, your country is hot, beware.

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.l: I see Castilians, that you marvel much
At this same emblem of the olive tree
Upon my back: lo this it signifies.
Spain is in wars, but London lives in peace,
Your native fruit doth wither on your soil,
And prospers where it never planted was.
This London's fealty doth avouch for truth,
Herald of war, and porter of their peace,
Command ye me no service to my lords.

sp.speaker: S. pride.
sp.p: Quid tibi cum domini mox servient miseri nobis: discede.

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.p: Quid mihi cum dominis servietis miseri meis ▪

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Shealty, say unto yon Thrasos thrée.
The lords of London dare them to the field,
Witting their pride and their ambition,
Scorning their tyranny, and yet fearing this,
That they are come from home and dare not fight,
But if they dare in joint or several arms,
Battle or combat, him that lucre seeks,
Your Spanish pride, him dare I from the rest.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: That bloody cur, your Spanish tyranny,
That London's conscience would force with cruelty,
I challenge him for conscience' sake to fight,
A lord of London, and I pleasure height.
And Shealty, when citizens dare them thus,
judge what our nobles and our courtiers dare ▪

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Say if thou wilt that London's policy
Discerns that proud ambition of sp●●●e,
And for he comes inflame with London's love,
In combat let him conquer me and have her,
This is love's favour, I her servant am.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: This Lucre's favour, pomp for her will fight.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: This conscience favour, she my mistress is.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: You craven English in your dunghill's crow.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: You Spanish pheasants crow upon your perch,
But when we fire your coats about your ears,
And take your ships before your walled towns,
We make a dunghill of your rotten bones,
And cram our chickens with your grains of gold.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: You will not yield?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Yes, the last month.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.p: Farewell. Retire heralds with the pages to their places.

sp.speaker: S. pride.
sp.p: Vade.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Herald, how now?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Then proud Castillians look for your service.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: So do we for theirs: but fealty, canst thou declare to me the cause why all their pages follow them, when ours in shows do ever go before.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: In war they follow, and the Spaniard is warring in mind

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: But that's not now the cause, yon three are pride, ambition tyranny.
Shame follows pride, as we a proverb have,
Pride goes before, and shame comes after,
Treachery ever attends upon ambition.
And terror always with a fearful watch,
Doth wait upon ill conscienced tyranny:
But why stay we to give them space to breathe:
Come, courage, let us charge them all at once.

div.stage: Let the three lords pass towards the Spaniards, and the Spaniardes make show of coming forward and suddenly depart.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: What braving cowards these Castillians be,
My lordes let's hang our scutcheons up again,
and shroud ourselves but not far off unseen,
To prove if that may draw them to some deed,
Be it but to batter our impressed shields.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Agreed, here fealty, hang them up a space.

div.stage: They hang up their shields, and step out of sight. The Spaniardes come and flourish their rapiers near them, but touch them not, and then hang up theirs, which the lords of London perceiving, take their own and batter theirs: the Spaniards making a little show to rescue, do suddenly slip away and come no more.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Facing, faint-hearted, proud and insolent,
That bear no edge within their painted sheaths,
That durst not strike our silly patient shields.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Up have they set their own, see if we dare
Batter on them, and beat their braving lords.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Let them not yonder hang unbacked, my lords.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: With good advice, that we be not surprised, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Myself will onset give on prides, at your peacock sir.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: At tyrannies will I bestow my blow, wishing the master.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: I at ambitions strike, have at his pampered jade.

div.stage: Enter s. pride.

sp.speaker: S. pride.
sp.p: Fuoro viliagos, fuoro lutheranos angleses, fuoro sa, sa, sa.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Their shields are ours, they fled away with shame,
But lordings, whiles the stratagem is fresh,
And memory of their misfortune green,
Their hearts yet fainting with the novel grief,
Let us pursue them flying, if you say it,
Haply, we may prevent their passage yet.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: With speed and heed the matter must be done,

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Therefore you policy shall our leader be.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes.
Enter three ladies and Nemo.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: The day is ours, fair ladies let us joy,
The joyful day that all men may rejoice,
Yet only I am thankful for this good.
And your good day at hand approacheth fast.
Wherein you shall be joined to thrée such lords,
as all the cities under heavens bright cope,
Cannot with all their glory match in worth,
Lucre, lord pomp a victor comes to thee:
Love, look thou for lord policy as well:
And conscience for her well reformed fere,
Pleasure, that only made his choice of her.
Upon that day triumphant shall we feast,
Wherein (Madames) your honours nil be least.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Against their coming might my read be hard,
Prepare would we garlands of laurel green,
To welcome them, more for the common good,
Than for affection private that we bear.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: To meet them coming will not be amiss,
But what know we how they will take such work,

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.l: Report may be much more than there is cause,
We may them meet and greet with joyful hearts,
And make them garlands when we know their minds.

div.stage: Enter the three lords with the Spanish shields and Diligence

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: And here they come with new impressed shields,
My lords well met, and welcome from your foes.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Lord pomp, well met, and welcome home again.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Lord policy, well met, and welcome home again.

sp.speaker: Conscience
sp.p: Lord pleasure, welcome with unfeigned heart.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Fair joy and lady xx. thousand thanks.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Fair love, and lady, twice as many thanks

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Fair and beloved lucre, though I speak last,
As kindly I thy welcome do accept,
As heart can think, pen write, or tongue can tell.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Now speak my lords, how have ye sped?

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Right well: thanks unto him that gave the day to us,
The pride of Spain was cloaked with majesty,
And shame his page, (Nicknamed) modesty,
Spanish ambition, honour would be called,
And treachery his page, termed action.
Their tyranny was cleped government,
Terror his page, was (Falsely) named regard,
But God above hath given them their reward.
They with dishonour left their shields behind,
The only prizes purchased by us now,
And those (Fair ladies) we present to you,
Love, this is thine, and he that gives it thee.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: In lieu whereof your gift and her I give
Again to you, that merit more than both.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: The greatest gift and good could me befall.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Fair lucre, lo, my present and myself.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Which I with Nemo's licence gladly take.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Take her lord pomp, I give her unto thee,
Wishing your good may ten times doubled be.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: The wished good this world could give to me.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Of duty I (My dear) must give thee this, that art my comfort and my earthly bliss.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Now lords, I hope you are contented all,
Pomp with his lucre, policy with love:
Pleasure with conscience, joy fall you from above:
And thus to you my promise is performed,
And I expect that yours as well be kept,
That present preparation may be made
To honour those with holy marriage rites,
That I in presence of the world may give
These as my daughters unto you my sons.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: By my consent one day shall serve us all,
Which shall be kept for ever festival.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And on that day in honour of these dames,
These shields in triumph shall be born about.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: With pageants, plates, and what delights may be to entertain the time and company.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: So it please you lordings, methinks it were meet,
That the ladies took care to provide their own toys.
Myself need to help them, who know their minds well,
For I can keep women both quiet and constant.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: It pleaseth us well that you will take the pains.
Fair ones, for a while we betake you to your business.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Ladies, adieu.The lords bring them to the door, and they go out and ne.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Beloved, farewell. Fra. gives Pol. a paper, which he reads and then saie●

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: It seems by this writing sir, you would serve me,
Is your name skill? whom did you serve last?

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: An ill master, my lord, I served none but myself.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Have ye never served any heretofore?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Yes, divers my lord, both beyond sea and here with your patience, my good lord, not offending the same, I think I am your poor kinsman, your lordship, policy, and I skill, if it like ye.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: You say very well, and it is very like, I will answer ye anon.

div.stage: Diss. gives plea. A paper which he reads, and says.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Is your name fair semblance that wish to serve me.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Please it your lordship, fair semblance, I am well seen, though I say it, in sundry languages, meet for your lordship, or any noble service, to teach divers tongues, and other rare things.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: I like ye very well, stay a while for your answer,

div.stage: Enter usury and gives a paper to pomp which he reads, and saith,

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Master usury, I thank ye that ye offer me your service, it seems to be for your old mistress' sake, lady lucre, stay but a while, I will answer you with reason.

div.stage: The three lords go together, and whisper, and call Diligence, Diligence goes out for a marking iron, and returns.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: How now my hearts, think ye we shall speed.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Diligence, come hither.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: I cannot tell what you shall, but I am sure I shall.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: I am as like as any of ye both.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: Fraud.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Whist man, he's skill.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.l: Skill, why dost thou seek to serve lady love?
What profit will that he?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Cut hold thee content, I'll serve but a while, and serve mine own turn and away.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Master usury come hither, you desire to serve me, you have done lady lucre good service you say, but it was against God and conscience you did it, neither ever in your life did ye any thing for love: well to be short, serve me you shall not, and I would I could banish you from London for ever, or keep you close prisoner, but that is not in me, but what is or may be, that straight you shall see: by policies counsel this shall be done, diligence bring that iron, help me my lords.

div.stage: Enter Diligence.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Give me the iron pomp, cousin skill help to hold him,
sp.stage: Fraud lays hold on him but diss. slip away.
sp.l: Sirrah, policy gives you this mark, do you see,
A little x. standing in the midst of a great. C,
Meaning thereby to let all men understand,
That you must not take above bare x. pound in the hundred at any hand,
And that too much too, and so be packing quietly:
And know that London's pomp is not sustained by usury,
But by well ventured merchandise and honest industry.

sp.speaker: Usury
sp.p: I would I had never seen ye, if this be your courtesy.

div.stage: Exit usury.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Now cousin skill, alias, filthy fraud,
No kinsman to policy, nor friend to the state.
In steed of serving me, diligence take him to Newgate,
Ask not why, sir, but diligence if he do strive,
Raise the street he's unweaponed, and thou hast a weapon on:
And now lords when ye will, about our affairs, let's be gone,

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Agreed, but what's become of fair semblance my man.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: A crafty villain, perceiving how we meant to usury, slipped away.

div.stage: Enter simplicity in haste, and give the lords a paper to read.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.l: All hail, all rain, all frost, and all snow, be to you thrée lords of London on a row:
Read my supplantation and my suit ye shall know,
Even for God's sake above, and three ladies' sakes below.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: M. diligence, do me favour, you know I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: Step aside till my lords be gone, I'll do for you what I can.

div.stage: Slip aside.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: What's here my boy, what's here? pleasure, this suit is sure to you, for it's mad stuff, and I know not what it means.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Neither do I: sirrah, your writing is so intricate, that you must speak your mind, otherwise, we shall not know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: You sue for three things here, and what be they tell them:

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p:
Cannot you thrée tell, and the suit to you thrée? I am glad a simple fellow yet, can go beyond you three great lords of London.
Why my suit, look ye, is such a suit, as you are bound in honour to hear, for it is for the puppet like wealth, I would have no new orders, nor new sciences set up in the city, whereof I am a poor freeman, and please ye, as ye may read in my bill there, simplicity freeman. But my lords, I would have three old trades, which are not for the common wealth, put down.

sp.speaker: Ple.
sp.p: And after all this circumstance, sir what be they?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: They be not thrée what lack yees, as what do ye lack, fine lockram, fine canvas, or fine holland cloth: or what lack ye, fine ballads, fine sonnets: or what lack ye, a purse or a glass, or a pair of fine knives: but they be three, have ye any's, which methinks are neither sciences nor occupations, and if they be trades, they are very malapert trades, and more than reason.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: As how sir? Name them.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Will you banish them as readily as I can name them? the first is, have ye any old iron, old male, or old harness?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: And what fault find ye with this?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: What fault? I promise ye a great fault, what have you or any man else to do to ask me if I have any old iron? What if I have, or what if I have not? Why should you be so saucy to ask?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Why fool, 'tis for thy good to give thee money for that, that might lie and rust by thee.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: No my lord, no. I may not call you fool: it is to mark the houses where such stuff is, that against rebels rise, there is harness and weapon ready for them in such and such houses, and what then? the rusty weapon doth wound passed surgery, and kills the Queen's good subjects: and the rest of the old trash will make them guns too, so it is good luck to find old iron, but 'tis naught to keep it, and the trade is crafty, and now my l. policy, I speak to you, 'twere well to put it down.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Wisely said, which is your second? Is that as perilous?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Yea, and worse: it is, have ye any ends of gold and silver? this is a perilous trade, covetous, and a ticement to murder, for, mark ye, if they that ask this should be evil given, as gods forbad ▪ they see who hath this gold and silver, may not they come in the night break in at their houses, and cut their throats for it? I tell ye, gold and silver hath caused as much mischief to be done as that, down with it.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: They that have it need not show it.

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p:
Tush, they need ask no such question, many a man hath delight
to show what he hath, the trade's a ticing trade, down with it:

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Now your third sir:

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: That is the craftiest of all, wherein I am disbus's, for that goes under the colour of simplicity, have ye any wood to clean?

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: A perilous thing, what hurt is there in this sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O do you not perceive the subtlety? why sir, the woodmongers hires these poor men to go up and down with their beetles and wedges on their backs, crying, have ye any wood to cleave, and laugh to see them travel so laden with wood and iron: now sir, if the poor men go two or thrée days and be not set a work (As sometimes they do) the woodmongers pay them and gain by it, for then know they there's no wood in the city, then raise they the price of billets so high, that the poor can buy none. Now sir, if these fellows were barred from asking, whether there were wood to cleave or not, the woodmongers need not know but that there were wood, and so billets and faggots would be sold all at one rate, down with this trade, we shall sit a cold else my lords.

sp.speaker: Ple.
sp.p: I promise you a wise suit, and done with great discretion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yea, is it not? might ye not do well to make me of your counsel I believe I could spy more faults in a week, than you could mend in a month:

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Well, for these three faults the time serves not now to redress:

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No marry, for you three must be married suddenly, and your feast must be dres●:

sp.speaker: Pom,
sp.p: Against which feast, repair you to diligence, and he shall appoint you furniture and money, and a place in the show, till when farewell. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Farewell my lords, farewell my three lords, and remember that I have set each of ye a fault to mend: well, I'll go seek m. diligence that he may give me forty pence against the feast sir reverence:Exit

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: What is it m. fraud, ye would demand of me? Dil and Frau. step out

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Sir this you know, though yourself be a man of good reckoning, yet are ye known an officer unto these three lords, and what discredit it were to me, being a noted man to pass through the streets with you being officer, or if any of my friends should suspect me with you, and dog us, and see me committed to Newgate, I were utterly discredited, here is a purse sir, and in it two hundred angels, look sir, you shall tell them.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: Here are so indeed, what mean ye by this, I will not take these to let ye escape.Deliver fraud the purse again.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I mean not so sir, nor I will not give half of them to be suffered to escape, for I have done no offence, though it please them to imprison me, and it is but on commandment, I shall not stay long, but I will give you this purse and gold in pawn to be true prisoner, only give me leave to go some other way, and home to my lodging, for my boots and other necessaries, for there I'll leave word I am ridden out of town, and with all the haste that possibly I may, I will meet you at Newgate, and give you an angel for your courtesy: there is the purse.

div.stage: Fraud gives him a purse like the other.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: I hazard (As you know) my lords displeasure herein, and yet to pleasure you I will venture this once, but I pray ye make haste that I be not shent, I would not for ten angels it were known.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: If I tarry above an hour, take that gold for your tarrying.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: I do not fear that you'll forfeit so much for so little cause. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Nemo with desire, delight, and devotion, the three lords of Lincoln.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: My lords of Lincoln, have you such title and such interest
To love, Lucre, and conscience, as ye say?
Who gave you leave to have access to them?
I am their father by adoption,
I never knew of love twixt them and you:
And to perpetual prison they were doomed,
From whence I only might deliver them.
Which at the suit of three most matchless lords,
Their countrymen, in London bred as they,
I have performed and freed them from their bonds,
And yet have bound them in their freedom too
To policy, to pleasure, and to pomp,
Three lords of London, whose they are in right,
Contracted wives, and done by my consent,
And even tomorrow is the marriage day,
Except your coming stay or break it off,
I will go call their lords to answer you,
The (Punder covert baron) meddle not. Exit.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.p: Fetch them lord Nemo, we will here attend.

sp.speaker: Delight.
sp.l: Attend we may, but unto little end,
The ladies are in hucksters handling now,

sp.speaker: Devo.
sp.l: I would I had my time in praying spent,
That I in wooing conscience did consume.

div.stage: Enter the three lords of London and Nemo.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.p: Here come the lords, let's show good countenance man.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Yet more ado before we can enjoy
The joys of marriage with our mistresses?
Be these the lords that title do pretend?
My lords of Lincoln, so we hear you be.
What are your names?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Devotion, desire, and delight.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Which comes for lucre?

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.p: I desire.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Which for conscience?

sp.speaker: Devo.
sp.p: I devotion.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Which for love?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: I delight.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: You shall be answered straight.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: I can answer them quickly: ye cannot have them, nor ye shall not have them.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Stay pleasure, soft: my lord desire, you lucre seek, desire of lucre (Be it without reproach to you my lord) is covetousness which cannot be separated long from that: read my lord.

div.stage: Point to the stone of care.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.p: In golden letters on this stone is written care.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Care with desire of lucre well agrees, the rather for that London's lucre may not be separated from London's pomp, so you may take that stone if ye will, but the lady you cannot have.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.p: And a stone is a cold comfort instead of lucre.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: Devotion to conscience (I speak now to you my lord that are learned) is sorrow for sin, or in one word read.

div.stage: Point to the stone of remorse.

sp.speaker: Deuot.
sp.p: On this sweating stone in brass is set remorse.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p:
And that is your portion, for conscience is bestowed on London's
pleasure, because London makes a conscience what pleasure they use and admit, and what time they bestow therein, and to what end: s● my lord devotion, either that or nothing.

sp.speaker: Devo.
sp.p: A stone is a hard lot in stod of a lady.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: My lord delight, that to delight in love, you must I love, for making choice of mine. Love is my portion, and that flint is yours.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Here in lead is written, charity: and what of this?

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: If you be (As I doubt not) honest delight in love, then in the best sense, you can have but charity, if you be (Which I suspect not) other delight in love, you must be noted for concupiscence, and that you will blush to be: well charity is your best, then that is your portion: for, mark ye, London's policy joins with London's love: to show, that all our policy is for love of London's common wealth: and so our love cannot be separate from our policy, you bear this.

sp.speaker: Delight.
sp.p: A flint's a hard change for so fair a wife.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.p: And thus lords, desire of lucre may take care, devotion of conscience may have remorse, and delight of love may have charity, other recompense none.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: And so we thrée leave you three with care, remorse, and charity.

div.stage: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.p: With care and remorse I swear, ye do leave us, but what charity I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Deuot.
sp.p: Well. yet must we use charity though we fail of our desire, and we are answered with such reason as is not to be gainsaid.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Indeed my lord your calling is to persuade to charity, but if I use patience, it shall be perforce.

sp.speaker: Devo.
sp.p: Yet being so wisely warned, methinks we should be armed and take this in worth, that the world wonder no further, I will take up my hard burden of remorse and be gone.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.p: It is good to follow examples of good, I'll take this heavy burden of care, and follow as I may.

div.stage: Exit

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Because I'll not be slagular, I'll frame myself to follow, taking this cold portion of charity as my share. Exit

div.stage: Enter simplicity with Diligence.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Come on m. diligence, I have been seeking ye, as a man should seek a load of hay in a needle's eye.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: And why hast thou sought me (I pray thee) so earnestly?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Why? For this ointment, these shells, these pleasure, do ye not know this countua mountus cum this d● mihi?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: What money, why? Do I owe thee any money?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: Owe me? Tush, no man, what do ye talk of owing? Come, and yet I must have some certain sigillatum et deliberatum in praesentia. Do you not understand sir? Forty pence and furniture by my lord pomp's appointment, against the wedding day: to be one of the show-makers, I do not say shoemakers, and yet they be honest men.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: I understand thee now, and thou shalt want neither money nor furniture for that: sawest thou not fraud lately?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No, a for ferret him, for if I could find him, I would make him fast enough for cozening me of ten shillings for certain copper buttons and rings, I thought to have been a haberdasher, and he hath made me worse than a haymaker.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: I may say to thee in counsel, but I'll have no words of it, he hath overreached me too: but if thou spy him first, let me understand, and if I see him first thou shalt have knowledge, for I'll tell thee, but laugh not, he showed me a purse with a hundred pound in angels, which he would deliver me in pawn to be my true prisoner, because for his credit, he was loath to go with me through the streets to Newgate: I refused it at first, but at last by his entreaty I was content to take his pawn, and thinking he had given me the right purse of gold, he had another like it, which he gave me with counters, and so went away, I never did see him since, but mum, no words of it.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: No words quoth 'a, that's a state test, would you be cozened so?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: Well, so it is now, come follow me for thy furniture and money.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter dissimulation and fraud in caps, and as the rest must be for the show.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: The coast is clear, come follow fraud and fear not, for who can decipher us in this disguise, thus may we shuffle into the show with the rest, and see and not be seen, doing as they do, that are attired like ourselves.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: That is, to stand amongst them, and take as they take, torches or any thing to furnish the show, now if we we can pass but this day unseen, let tomorrow shift for itself as it may, I promise thee dissimulation thou art very formal.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Not more than thyself fraud, I would thou sawest thy picture

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.p: Picture here, picture there, let's follow our business. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter a Mench singing.
div.l: Strow the fair flowers and herbs that be green,
To grace the gayest wedding that ever was seen.
If London list to look, the streets were ne'er so clean,
Except it was when best it might, in welcome of our Queen:
Three lovely lords of London shall three London ladies wed,
Strow sweetest flowers upon the stones, perfume the bridal bed.
div.stage: Enter first Diligence with a truncheon, then a boy with policies lance and shield, then policy and love hand in hand: then fraud in a blue gown, red cap and red sleeves, with ambition's lance and shield, then a boy with pomps lance and shield, then pomp and Lucre hand in hand: then dissimulation with pride's lance and shield, then a boy with pleasure's lance and shield: then pleasure and conscience hand in hand: then simplicity with tyrannies lance and shield: they all going out, Nemo stays and speaks.

lg.l: These lords and ladies thus to church are gone,
An honoured action to solemnize there,
With greater joy will they return anon,
Than Caesar did in Rome his laurel wear.
Lord policy hath love unto his fere.
Lord pomp hath lucre to maintain his port,
Lord pleasure conscience to direct his sport.
Usury is marked to be known,
Dissimulation like a shadow fleets,
And simony is out of knowledge grown,
And fraud unfound in London but by fits.
Simplicity with painful penury sits.
For hospitality that was wont to feed him,
was slain long since and now the poor do need him.
That hospitality was an honest man,
But had few friends (Alas) if he had any,
But usury which cut his throat as than
Was succoured, and sued for by many.
Would liberality had been by thy side,
Than hospitality, thou hadst never died.
But what mean I, one of the marriage train,
To mourn for him will ne'er be had again.
His ghost may walk to mock the people rude:
Ghosts are but shadows, and do sense delude:
I talk too long, for so this lovely crew
Are coming back, and have performed their due.

div.stage: Return as they went, saving that the blue gowns that bore shields, must now bear torches: simplicity going about, spies fraud, and falleth on his knees before pleasure and conscience, saying.

sp.speaker: Simplicity ▪
sp.l: O lady conscience that art married to lord pleasure,
Help thy servant simplicity to recover his lost treasure:
A boon my lords, all for love and lucre's sake,
Even as you are true lords, help a false lout to take,

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Thou shalt have help, speak, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.l: See you yon fellow with the torch in his hand?
One the falsest villain that is in this land,
Let him be laid hold on that he run not away,
And than ye shall hear what I have to say.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Diligence bring him hither, good lords and ladies stay,

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.l: O master fraud, welcome to the butts,
Now I'll have my ten shillings in spite of your guts,
The French tanker consume ye, you were an old Frenchman,
Dam goll button, goll renga, bugla lase, you cozened me then,
My lords I beseech ye that at Tyburn he may totter,
For instead of gold, the villain sold me copper.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Is this true m. skill?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
It is true in a sort my lord, I thought to be pleasant with him being my old acquaintance, and disguised myself like an old French
artificer and having a few copper knacks, I sold them to him to make sport for ten shillings, which money I am content to pay him again so shall he have no loss though he have made a little sport.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: First give him an angel before my face. Simplicity, art thou pleased?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly I am pleased to take a good angel for ten shillings, speciously of such a debtor as m. fraud: but now I am to be pleased otherwise, that is, to see him punished, I promise ye the people love him well, for they would leave work and make half holiday to see him hanged.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: That his punishment may please thee the better, thou shalt punish him thyself: he shall be bound fast to yon post, and thou shalt be blindfold, and with thy torch shalt run as it were at tilt, charging thy light against his lips, and so (If thou canst) burn out his tongue, that it never speak more guile.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O singulariter nominativo, wise lord pleasure: genetivo bind him to that post, dativo, give me my torch, accusat. For I say he's a cozener. Vocat. O give me room to run at him. Ablat. take and blind me. Pluraliter, per omnes casus. Laugh all you to see me in my choler adust to burn and to broil that false fraud to dust.

div.stage: Bind fraud, blind simplicity, turn him thrife about, set his face towards the contrary post, at which he runs, and all to burns it, Dis. standing behind fraud, unbinds him, and whiles all the rest behold Simp. they two slip away: pleasure missing fraud saith.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.p: Wisely performed, but soft sirs, where is fraud? O noble villain, gone whiles we beheld the other: who loosed him? Who let him slip? well, one day he will pay for all: unblind simplicity.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p: How now, have I beated his lips? have I warmed his nose? and scorched his face? Let me see, how looks the villain? Have I burned him?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: Thou hast done more, for thou hast quite consumed him into nothing, look, here is no sign of him, no not so much as his ashes.

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.p:
Very few ashes if there be any, ye may see what a hot thing anger is, I think that the torch did not waste him so much as my wrath: well, all London, nay, all England is beholding to me, for putting fraud out of this world, I have consumed him and brought him to nothing
and I'll tread his ashes under my feet, thatno more frauds shall ever spring of them: but let me see, I shall have much anger, for the tanners will miss him in their leather, the tailors in cutting out of garments, the shoemaker in closing, the tapsters in filling pots, and the very oistermen to mingle their oysters at Billingsgate, yet it is no matter the world is well rid of such a crafty knave.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Well now thou art satisfied, I wish all here as well contented,
And we my lords that praise this happy day,
Fall we on knees and humbly let us pray.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: First that from heaven upon our gracious Queen,
All manner blessings may be multiplied,
That as her reign most prosperous hath been,
During world's length so may it still abide,
And after that with saints be glorified·
Lord grant her here health, hearts-ease, joy and mirth.
And heaven at last, after long life on earth.

sp.speaker: Policy
sp.l: Her counsel wise, and nobles of this land
Bless, and preserve oh lord with thy right hand.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: On all the rest that in this land do dwell,
Chiefly in London, lord pour down thy grace,
Who living in thy fear and dying well,
In heaven with angels they may have a place.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
